It's vital to understand that this game is a platform. The things you can do in Arma 3 vary substantially as you explore the well made campaign, community made missions, and popular pvp game modes. Without downloading any of the amazing free mods, Arma 3 has the potential to provide some of the greatest experiences of natural vicious combat possible in gaming. When played with a microphone with or without known friends, teamwork effortlessly comes as you end up doing whatever you can to NOT DIE.   Because the game has so many options to play, you may find yourself playing boring game modes, or thrown together single player community made missions. This is why I'd like to recommend a couple ways for you to enjoy this astonishing. Creating or joining a group delving into medium to large scale COOP encounters is absolutely staggering. While some groups require entire application processes, more casual ones exist that are still incredibly fun such as Reddit's /r/ProjectAwesome. If you just wanna jump in for a a couple hours instead of scheduling events a week in advance, check out the ever present King of the Hill servers (preferably infantry only). Whatever you do, USE A MIC and DON'T BE SHY! You get from this game what you put into it so interacting with others will enhance your enjoyment tremendously.  Once you find the way you like to play here, I can promise, despite its flaws, that every facet of design will coalesce into a truly unique experience that will give you mind numbing moments you will never forget.

I want to start off saying that I absolutely love this game.. Fps drops, glitches, screwed up animations, and exploits. When I first started playing Arma 3, it was beautiful. I had no problems running this game at all. With the last three updates it has gotten worse each time. Bohemia needs to finish the game and test their content before the release it to ruin the gameplay experience for their hefty price tag on this title. When this game is functioning properly, it's by far one of the best games I've ever played and by far the most realistic. It has very diverse gameplay, with many mods available via  armaholic.com  and the DLC that they've released with the game.   So in summary, if I'm paying 59.99 for Arma 3 and also buying their DLC, along with all of the other paying customers. The developers of said title should have enough funds and the ability to ensure that their game works properly.

This is one of the most interesting and expansive games out there. The current storyline and background is a bit unrealistic-The Republic of Altis and Stratis has a super-advanced military but the nation has under 50,000 people in its population. The population also is Greek, but for whatever reason all speaks english-even the armed forces. Nonetheless, the mission editing is superb compared to Arma 2, the mechanics are mostly improved (animation and AI needing a bit of a change for realism) the voice acting for British and American English as well as Farsi is superb. Iran has a huge presence in the game, however it is never mentioned and instead goes under the quite unrealistic banner of Canton-Protocol Strategic Alliance Treaty, or CSAT. I really wish that BIS would at least include the Iran flag above the CSAT insignia on the uniforms, for it looked absolutely amazing when this was the case at E3 2011. Physics in the game are great, however the fabled ragdoll physics are a bit dissapointing. All they seem to do is make units die in a more unrealistic-looking way. NATO is portrayed as completely bankrupt which really bothers me-unemployment is at freaking 50% in the US. It is interesting to see future interpretations of the US Army, which use the new multicam pattern in their uniforms. I am bothered by the lack of ANY, yes ANY authentic equipment in the game. This is perhaps my biggest problem, for it gives the developers an excuse to make fantasy content for every upcoming Arma game. Yes, it saves on lisencing, but the developers just launched a 650-thousand dollar modding contest. A fraction of the money could have been spent on making the weapons and vehicles authentic.   With a host of friends to play with, some mods, and an open mind, this title is one of the most awesome games I have ever played. The simulation of the vehicles is amazing, with support for almost every joystick, controller, or other external device you can think of. The game fails to provide an immersive atmosphere but is a fun and engaging way to play COOP with friends, strategy being completely necessary. The graphics are in my top 10 games ever, and the performance is better than with Arma 2, especially if you plan on making Youtube videos like I do. (check out my Youtube channel: FistoGames :D ) Go and buy it. With some DLC's that bring it back to where Arma 2 was in scenario, it will definitely be an amazing game.

Handcuffed by 3 men. Took my shirt and my pants off. They took deep breaths into the mic. All three stole a bags worth of blood from me. Hit me once with their fist each. Left me to die. Broke out. Found a crowbar. Killed one. Ran away. Crawled into a house almost dead. Had a friend come save me. I wasnt gonna be able to make it i thought. We went into another city looking for a blood bag. Upon entering the hospital we were greated by one of the men that almost killed me. The blasted my friends brains on me. I ran out as fast as the game would let me. I ran to a town. Shot after shot was fired at me. I kept yelling into the mic 'You suck at shooting!' Nearing at the town i was hit once. I crawled up to the top floor and used my only rag to stop bleeding. By this point i knew I was gone. Tears were streaming down my face as I wished it didnt have to happen like this. I could hear him running along the floor below me looking for me. He came out of the doorway from the stairs and i scream 'WAIT!'... He pointed his gone at me. I closed my eyes and braced myself. nothing happened..... I looked him in the eyes as he looked at mine. I told him the bad things i did. I told him about my family. My friend that he killed. I told him how what they did to me i had deserved it. I could see tears streaming down his face. He looked at me and told me something. He told me how he knew i killed one of his friends. He told me how the other was shot in a shoot out. His face soaked with tears he pointed the gun at me. I said 'no need. we have both lost something.' He put the gun down. 'We can end this together. No need for anymore violence. We dropped our stuff and walked to the edge. I looked to my right and he looked to his left. we both said 'Thank you..' at the exact same time. We both jumped off the edge and died right next to each other. i felt my soul leave my body.  Then i respawned

The campaign is a thrilling story of a young Corporal Kerry who you'll play as. The maps are EXTREMELY detailed everywhere, there are so many cool and breath-taking areas of the two islands of Stratis and Altis. There are tons of servers and gamemodes so you can't be bored. There is also the option to mod this game in so many cool and fantastic ways it seems endless! But be warned, the controls are not so easy, they are not your simple stand, crouch, prone. The vehicle's controlling is decent but you will likely need some practice for the jets and helicopters which I had to do. The AI's path-taking and combat skills are impressive, at times they can act stupid. This game is a must-have for the computer gamer! I give this game a solid 5 out of 5 stars for its gameplay. I would recommend this game to anyone interested in a next level military simulation game. The developer's team is bunch of people who really do know what they are doing to make this game outstanding to play. This is not a game where you might think of a bunch of kids acting like they are United States Navy Seals or British SAS, you should think this game as a serious, fun, educational game of how military might work and fight in a simulated warzone. I hope this review encourages you to buy the game AND the DLC for it! I know I will be a constant customer with the amount of great work the developers have done to Arma 3.

Despite many of its early faults, Bohemia Interactive - as well as the always extremely-active ArmA community of modders et al - really pulled the ArmA universe to a whole new level. The graphics are only the beginning of the immersive environment: realistic projectile ballistics (as well as surprisingly detailed terminal ballistic effects), well-done animations (especially of essential combat tasks, like reloading), and the variable stance/lean system. Unfortunately, there are a few problems that have plagued ArmA since the beginning of time, namely the AI. I say this because even after becoming intimately familiar with the game and the teammate command system, detailed commands are bulky at best. AI as a whole tends to be relatively oblivious when it comes to medium- and 'crew-served' weapons; the suppressive fire command does absolutely nothing with your machinegunners and autoriflemen, and anti-tank gunners apparently forget they have 15 pound rocket launchers strapped to their backs and decide their small arms are the most effective weapons against MBTs. The aerial platforms' damage models could be improved as well (i.e.: losing parts of the aircraft when you clip a tree or wires rather than just exploding), however, this would require a lot more work than may be worth it at this point - perhaps later in A3's lifetime. Fortunately to me, despite these (at times) fatally annoying flaws (*cough* AI *cough*) nothing in the virtual world comes close to the level of accuracy (both from the vanilla BI platform and the ArmA communities' multiple mods) that ArmA 3 delivers.

I absolutely love Arma 3 and would in every way recommend it to anyone with even a passing interest. There are somewhat valid criticisms of it which I will get out of the way right away, before getting into why the pros by far outweigh the cons. 1. Lack of Content - One of the more popular criticisms of this game is the lack of official content in the current build, especially compared to the amount of content in Arma 2. The two main factions currently (at the time of writing this review) have no fixed wing aircraft, armoured vehicles of different factions have the same turrets and weapons merely reskinned (artillery, anti-air and remote controlled turrets on smaller vehicles) and UAVs/UGVs are identical for all factions except for different camo patterns. 2. Performance - Another often heard criticism of Arma 3 is that it performs very poorly on some machines that it often should perform well on. Like machines with top-end graphics cards and powerful CPUs.  Addressing these points one by one, I will say that while there is content missing that even I would have expected the game to have at release, it isn't a whole lot. Arma 2 did not have all the content it does today at it's release either, and much of it is inflated by there being separate entries for guns with different attachment combinations, so that the same gun with four different sight attachments would show up in a list as four different guns. As for the performance issues, the game runs perfectly fine on my middle-of-the-road gaming rig and runs at playable rates on the old low to mid-end machine of my best friend. The performance of the game on some people's high-end machines is in no way a sure indicator of bad optimization, especially when the same game runs great on other machines with the same hardware.  Now getting to the real meat of the review. The visuals of this game are amazing, especially if you have the power to crank up the graphics settings. The lighting is great and makes the game look heavenly, especially at night. The texture quality is top notch, especially for foliage and I fully believe anyone interested in first person shooters, should experience one where you can freely roam a huge 270 square kilometer beautifully rendered island with a rendering distance of several kilometers. Other cool graphical features are the volumetric fog and clouds as well as rain that is rendered as independent particle effects for each raindrop in stead of a mere filter or overlay.  Audio-wise the game could do with some improvements that are guaranteed to happen over time, if not by Bohemia Interactive, then by community modders, however overall the sound design of this game is really quite good as it is.  The gameplay is where Arma 3 really shines over it's predecessor, as controls of your soldier have been improved to feel a lot more direct and fluid than in previous games, though the action menu still tends to limits how good the game can feel in certain situations. The inventory system has seen huge improvements from Arma 2 and is much more streamlined, without sacrificing flexibility. Vehicles are now physics simulated objects, which is a huge improvement over Arma 2's incredibly janky vehicle physics. Underwater gameplay is a really nice addition that looks amazing and gives mission makers a lot more freedom and variety to work with, when making missions and giving the players different approaches to completing them. Firing weapons in Arma 3 feel pretty damn good as most rifles have a good deal of kick to them, making them both sound AND feel powerful in stead of feeling like Call of Duty or Battlefield style bullet-hoses. Different weapon calibers penetrating diferent materials differently at different angles and distances gives both the shooters and the people being shot at a lot of things to think about and decide how to react to in every firefight, which is great in a game that is so decidedly slow paced as Arma is, compared to other first person shooters.  If you get this game and want to dive straight into some fun Arma 3 gameplay, I suggest playing though the first episode of the single-player campaign first, to get acquainted with the fairly complex controls and spotting/shooting enemies at ranges that other FPS games would never expect you to. Once you feel somewhat at home in the game, I highly recommend looking for a multiplayer server running the Wasteland mission, which is sort of like a 3-way Team Deathmatch gamemode with survival elements, base-building, resource gathering and impromptu mini-missions against AI that all of the three teams are given and can undertake at the same time, each team trying to beat the others for the promised reward, leading to some very interesting clashes.  So all in all, I can barely recommend this game enough, but to get some real enjoyment out of it, you'll want to run it on a decent mid to high-end rig.

Ah where to begin with ARMA 3....   I had just landed on a beach in a rubber boat with my four man team. We are assaulting enemy positions to capture intel and eliminate a HVT. Soon after landing, we are ambushed by an enemy assault boat that promply decimates my team. I manage to land a rocket hit on the boat and incapacitate its crew before it can annihilate me. With the boat disabled, I am now on my own. Do I continue the mission by myself, or do I abort and let my team die for nothing? I choose to continue, using a silenced weapon to help conceal my position. I call for friendly reinforcments to begin the assault on the town. A convoy with friendly troops starts coming down the road. Suddenly, rockets from a hilltop position begin to rain down on the convoy, disabling several vehicles. Everyone dismounts and begins engaging the enemy on the hilltop. I use the distraction to flank the enemy position and eliminate the fireteam. We proceed towards the town, eliminating small pockets of resistance along the way. Suddenly we are pinned down by enemy machinegun fire that kills several friendlies. I call in an airstrike that levels the houses containing the position, eliminating the threat along with the HVT. I then see a target of opportunity: an enemy cargo truck. I align my sights slightly above the target to compensate for the distance and fire. The truck erupts into flames. This came at a price, as my postion was compromised and drew heavy enemy fire towards my position. We have no choice but to engage. After several bloody minutes, four enemy fireteams lay dead on the battlefield with only light casualties on our side. I decide this is the moment to assault the position containing the intel. I successfully acquire the intel and call in an evac chopper to extract me to a safe position. We extract under fire and secure the intel, dealing a severe blow to the enemy.  10/10

This game is breath-taking, whether you like fast-paced gunfights, long-range sniper duels, monster-trucking it with M1A2 Slammer tanks, playing Ace Combat with incredibly fluid movement, raiding a small outpost of hostile forces with a attack helicopter, playing a role in week long, server-wide wars, doing night raids on an enemy research facility, setting up a UAV to perform reconnissance on enemy camps, packing your scuba gear and checking out the lost treasures of Altis and Stratis, or just hopping in a plane and enjoying the wide, vast, beauty of this game! This game is absolutley wonderful. I have played about 11 hours of this game and i have not gotten bored yet. There is so much you can do in this game without even touching the multiplayer portion such as ; Build your own missions (scenarios). Yes, you can build your own missions once and if you get bored of the main campaign or you finish it. (2) The campaign- Now if you have the Apex DLC, you will have 2 campaigns available. I have not played the Apex campaign but the main campaign is absolutley exciting. If you are looking for a campaign similar to COD or Battlefield, then this is not for you, the missions require strategic thinking and smart tactics, you have to actually look for the enemies instead of them popping out in front of you. There is also no respawning (which some people may not like). However, you have the ability to patch yourself up after taking a non-critical hit and the game auto saves after passing certain points throughout the level. (3) Mods- Mods are a great addition to the game. You can either get Scenario mods, Campaign mods, Vehicle and Unit mods, or Game changing mods which mean they will put you through another Era in time and you can either download scenarios or campaigns with these mods. Examples of these are : Iron Front 3 for Arma, and Unsung vietnam. You can grab IFA3 here on the steam workshop, however you will have to do some searching for Unsung, it can be found on MODDB. Last but not least is Multiplayer. Now i have not played very much of the multiplayer becasue in my opinion, to really get the most out of multiplayer you should play it with friends. Now that is not to say don't play multiplayer because you dont have anyone to play it with, but communication is key in some game modes. Hope this review helped you in deciding whether or not to get this masterpiece of a game. Enjoy.

I have owned this game for a number of weeks now and I have been completely hooked. Great game for the more serious war gamer, not for those who prefer the fast paced combat that you get from Call of Duty series which I consider more for the younger gamers anyway.  Arma 3 moves a lot slower and is more squad based than other war games, similar to Battlefield series only slower than that when playing online and you may find yourself on 10 minute helicopter rides just to get into the battlefield and you will be highly satisfied with each kill you make as you know a single round landed by your enemy could be fatal regardless of the weapon they are using. You will have to make good use of any cover you can find and hit the dirt as soon as you hear a bullet crack over your head and then very carefully survey the surrouding area and work out where you are taking fire from as it will usually not be obvious where the fire is coming from and you will find yourself having to hold up for 10-20 minutes in a single location (sometimes longer, I personally have gotten pinned in one location for over an hour) because you are either pinned by enemy fire or it is too dangerous to move forward.  You will need to buffer up on your mic communication skills as most players use proper phonetics etc when relaying information to each other on the battlefield such as coordinates and other reconaissance.  You can not respawn as quickly as you can in CoD if you are taken down by enemy fire so staying alive is more crucial than any other war game you have played and you wanna hope you are moving up with a squad that has a medic.  The graphics are great, the game is a little glitchy at times and the controls take a little getting used to.  I recommend buying this game to any serious war game enthusiasts who want to get as close to war as possible (unless doing paintballing or airgunning), and if you do buy the game - I recommend completing the whole VR Tutorial before actually joining a server or playing the Campaign as you will need to really learn all those different keys that may make the difference in a hairy situation in game.

I've always meant to write a review for this game, after spending 1,700 hours in it. God knows how many hours I've spent on Arma 2. Anyways, this is one of the best games I've ever played. While I might describe this as a game, I consider this as more of an engine. Why?   Because games often restrict you to a lore, a path, tools, programed in a way without giving you the chance to explore other possibilities; they want you to experience what they want you to experience. For this game, it's different - you can choose to be a common soldier in the Vietnam war. You can choose to be a helicopter pilot in the war in Iraq. Whatever theatre, faction, weapon, uniform you fancy, there are often mods for it.   So forget about how badly optimized this game is, because the fact is with how vast the possibilities this game opens you to, you really are pushing the boundaries of this engine. People often complain about how badly optimized this game is, and at the same time complain about the lack of free will in other games. This game has the latter, so appreciate it for what it is.   The community is one of the best out there. But because of the influx of new players, also be wary of who you might run into.

There are lots of bugs and poor design choices, that's for sure. The graphics aren't that great and the game runs like crap (sometimes 25 fps on my top end system). The game can also be really boring and frustrating (like when you get stuck on rocks and have to restart a 2 hour mission).  That said, I definitely recommend this game for someone who's tired of the same ol arcade shooters. Before I played Arma, I thought Battlefield 3 was a military simulator (lel). This game is nothing like call of duty. In arcade shooters like CoD, there's tons of action, all the time, and it gets mind numbing. In Arma, action is pretty infrequent, but when it does happen it's really intense and unforgiving. The missions are also very sandbox; you can plan out your own strategies instead of just running through ACTIONPACKED!!!!!, repetitive levels.  It's a hard game to learn. It uses almost every button on the keyboard. To this day I still don't know how to do some things, such as use laser guided bombs. If you're looking for a challenging, intense 'true pc game' you can't go wrong with Arma III.

This is one of the most complicated FPS games to play, as in there are a lot of control you need to learn to make your character move around in a organized way. Once you learn them however, the games becomes very fun, and difficult. So if you dont like a challenge this game is not for you. Some parts of the campaign I had to try (on regular) at least 20-30 times. Im a decent FPS player but is like no other I've played.   The game itself is very nice to look at, albeit not as optimized as I would like to see. It is also very heavility CPU based. My OC 4790k hovers around 20-50% usage, sometimes going into the high 60s. I play on very high at 5760x1080 and get around 55-70 fps on average with 970 SLI.   The gameplay is very different then any other game. The audio and realism is very good. Sometimes you really think you are a soldier and get scared when you are walking and suddenly hear bullet impacts near you. The gunplay is also very hard and challenging. You have to really be slow and careful on where you are how you plan to engage the enemy. Because they are very good shots and you die very easily. So you have to be strategic in everything you do. Which can be really fun.   This also is not a non-stop action game. There is a lot of walking and exploring. This is like a COD polar opposite.   Mods and custom content really add to the replayability and fun of this game. The fun never stops when you have all of the steam workshop and a few friends to play with.   Some things did bother me and broke the realism for me. One being that a nice combat simulator like this with accurate gun behaviors and recoil doesnt even have 2 different reload animations for guns, or when reloading when not empty you don't get 30+1. Also there is not very good animation in this game, reload, talking, and some player animation is not very smooth or realistic in many cases.   Overall I give it a 8/10 for what it was planning/supposed to be and how I received it.

TL;DR: Pros: -Extreme realism (damage, movement, fatigue, healing, equipment, ect...) -(sink or swim) training of very valuable combat skills used in real life and useful in other games -very useful AI companions (most of the time) -everything has a counter and can be taken down with the right equipment and/or exceptional skill and/or lucky shots Cons: -Extreme difficulty (probably harder than darksouls at times, save often between engagements and stay with your team) -Characters occasionally feel emotionally stunted -obvious 'god mode' NPC sometimes (coughcoughfirstmissioncoughcough)  Too Long;Read it anyway:  One of the most realistic warfighter simulators to date. As such, it's also difficult to the point where anyone who plays a 'standard' FPS will quickly die due to lack of caution. Everything is simulated to an extreme degree from the problems associated with exaustion and fatigue resulting in slower movement and trouble aiming, to the reality of taking fire causing tunnel vision, realistic injuries, and extremely quick death.   One of the first lessons you will learn in this game is to keep your head down and look for cover. Always be looking for ways to find your enemies before they find you and never take any advantage for granted. The second someone knows where you are before you know where they are, you are at a crippling disadvantage as it is all too easy to line up a steady shot and kill someone before they even knew you where there. A good way to learn just how scary it is on the modern battlefield today for anyone involved since you'll find yourself relying on your AI and player teammates almost more than you rely on your own skills. You might find yourself actually following around the AI for cues and clues on how to fight and the level of communication between both players and the AI allies is far above what most games have ever accomplished on a practical level. Simply put, this game has NPCs that you may actually find a bit of value in compared to the inaccurate, incompetent, prescripted 'spehshul farces' NPCs you see in other games  The actual campaign is pretty good too, giving you a good look (in my opinion) of what combat arms guys would actually deal with in a desprate situation (out numbered and out gunned in a hostile foriegn country with little in the way of support) I wont tell you how things got this way, but right from the start, the entire remaining NATO forces (in that particular area of operations) are hanging on by a thread and fighting a larger, albiet less experianced, local military and it's extremely satisfying to survive each mission and see the desperate struggle continue.   Now as great as the AI is in this game, it's not without it's flaws. They are skilled, but occasionally have path finding issues in vehicles that make you wonder who gave these guys their license. In the campaign, occasionally the 'god mode' will kick in and reveal that the character is obviouslly story critical before they actually are but it's rare enough that you won't be annoyed by it long and chances are that you'll be too busy trying to stay alive to notice it.   There is also the fact that I think that maybe they could have increased the emotional factor by allowing the characters to grieve a bit more over the loss of their buddies during and after combat, as sometimes it feels a little cold that they just ignore it other than a call out that someone's down. You see it effect them every once in a while for certian characters but really it seems they either aren't really feeling it right then or are really good at not showing it which is something that legitimately happens so I find it forgivable for the devs to have not made the call outs for each death a little more emotional. There is another factor I think could play into why they can keep it to '(number) is down' but for spoiler sake, I won't say that theory here.
ArmA 3 is the definitive warfare simulator.

'The best sandbox war game of the year'  Arma 3 is a continuation to the Arma series by Bohemia Interactive, taken to the next level. With increased player control/movement, enhanced mechanics for vehicles, weapon systems (if you buy it), flight models (if you buy it -_-), and much more! The control in tight spaces should be worked on, this is no call of duty, the controls are clunky, but are a vast improvement over the previous installment (arma 2). Another of the top complaints of this game is the NETCODE. It is terrible under load, but again, is much better than arma 2.   This game is mostly open source, Meaning that players are able to change almost every aspect of the game from the amount of fog to adding dinosuars into the game. The things you can do are endless and that is it's selling point. Bohemia Interactive leaves the imagining to you and the community to come up with your own story or missions. This game is heavily supported by the modding community and for good reason. The scripting language for ARMA 3 is .sqf, Based off the C++ coding language, but it seems like a little of everything works. (there is alot of things you can do to make somehting work) I have based 4 years of my life modding and playing arma 2 and arma 3, making this my most played game, by a long shot.  The best way to play this game is modded and with friends. By it's self, arma is fun, but somewhat bland, but that seems like that was part of the plan... BI (Bohemia Interactive) made the game as basic as possible to allow you and it's users to change it the way they like it!   Do I recommend this game?  YES!   This game has supplied my friends and I countless hours of playtime with new and exciting missions and firefights, and with a few basic mods it has become 400% better than before.   9.2/10

Don't mistake this game for an FPS, some people enter into this game expecting COD ...it's not. ARMA is a full battlefield simulator which it does well at. In ARMA you're not meant to feel invincible, if you don't take cover you'll die, if you don't communicate with your squad you'll die. It has an insane learning curve that will take most people a long time to get used to, but only makes it very satisfying once you finally figure out how to fly or use artillery or...anything. The complicated controls at first can seem annoying but once you're used to them you'll be grateful you can stick your head up just enough to see an enemy out of a window without exposing your whole body.  The games mod-ability makes it possible to play an infinite array of game modes making it difficult to get truly boring. While there is a battlefield like mod called king of the hill the size of the maps alone makes the game vastly more complex and that's saying nothing of the array of vehicles that can completely alter the game from just one player knowing how to fly or range a sniper rifle.   Unfortunately the ARMA engine is well known for how glitchy it can get, Most of this has been ironed out and the presence of hackers ruining servers has been greatly reduced since early access. At times clipping through a wall or falling through the floor of a building still happens but it's not so common that it ruins things.  At the end of the day the game requires being patient and on your toes while communicating what you see with teammates. The different mods and game modes give the game infinite potential but the glitches can create issues sometimes. ARMA 3 is a military sim not 'insert FPS here' don't get attached to scores and if you find yourself complaining over global that someone using a plane is 'cheap' or a 'noob' close the game and reevaluate who you want to be in life.

Arma III; great game, but...  Arma III checks all the boxes for a simulation. Incredible graphics, massive scope, high level of detail, everything a person would want for a simulation. The short time I played it, I was blown away by its realism. Therein, lies the problem.  Arma III continues a trend I noticed first with the Gran Turismo series of games. GT2 was an fun game to play. A little cartoonish with the graphics and not entirely accurate to real life, but it was real enough to enjoyable. Since then, the Gran Turismo games have become more realistic and I'm in awe everytime a trailer comes out. I haven't bought a game since GT3. GT3 wasn't fun to play, it was too real. The cars required a level of control that I couldn't provide using a controller and TV screen. This is the same issue I have with Arma.  The first time my character died, I think I was receiving fire from in front of me. Each time after that, I couldn't tell you where I was being shot from. After the 10th or 15th time, enough was enough. It was very realistic, and very frustrating. No feedback from my speakers, or anything on screen to indicate where the enemy was. Effectively, I was being punished for playng a computer game on a computer. WASD and a mouse werenot enough for me to play this game.  To sum up:  If you enjoy shooters like Halo or Doom, this might not be for you.  If you were frustrated by the unforgiving nature of MS Flight Simulator, this game is definitely NOT for you.  If you have a thing for playing the most realistic games available, this is the game for you!

This is my first review. Arma 3 is one of the most realistic military sim you'll play in awhile. The realism beats battlefield, but is slower. At first if you're not use to it you will wonder how you died. After awhile you will realize that you were shot around 500 meters away. ARMA 3 is for the players who want more realism than battlefield.The game has many positives and some negatives that I can note.  Positives: + Amazing graphics in some places + Big maps (2 really big islands, with one about 270km squared) +A decent amount of vehicles / weapons  +Alot of uniforms for player customization (using the virtual ammo box, that is present in some servers) + A very good editor and a real time edior named zeus (now 3D) + Life like situations with other players + No annoying kids like in Call Of Duty Negatives: - The campaign does leave an impression - The AI downright has no IQ - Needs a good computer - The map ,though big, some places is really just open land (unless is apex then trees everywhere) - Hard to learn The game has it's shares of positives and negatives, but will not be like any other game you've ever played. Don't buy this game if you won't take the time to learn how to play. That is because it will overwhelm you if you perfer games like Call of Duty.

TL;DR: Very good game. Get it if its not already in your library. If it is in your library get it for a friend.  This game is a very solid entry in the Arma franchise. It improves upon Arma 2 in every way besides content. But that is even made up for in mods. If youve played Arma 2 and enjoyed it, then youll love this. If you havent played any Army before, youll still love this. It is a must buy. But ill explain why that is my review.  Pros: -This game has very good graphics and well optimised -I would go as far to say this is the most 'realistic' combat game out there -There is loads of content in the Steam Workshop for many hours of fun and tons of mods and game modes -The PvP is simply the best PvP in any game Ive ever played, and Ive played a lot of games -Compared to the last Arma it improves in all areas (besides content- Ill cover that in the Cons) -There is very few squeakers and trollers, and it has a mature player base.  -New inventory system is very well done -The sound in this game is amazing.   Cons: -It will absolutely â¥â¥â¥â¥ your PC. You need a good graphics card to run this game. (It runs like a champ if you have a good card) -Lack of weapons and vehicles. (But it makes up for it by having a great attatchment system) -This is not for impatient people. Nearly every mission will have you walk at least 1km. Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. I do recommend this game, but there is something that you need to know about this game.... This game is not the most optimized game out there, your PC might struggle like hell. You can enjoy this game if your PC specs meet the requirement, even so you might face FPS drop during gameplay (explosion, etc.). This game is CPU intensive, if you experience FPS drop, there's a chance it is caused by your CPU (unless you set the graphics all the way to high then your GPU might be the case too).  This is a military simulation game, if you like games like Call of Duty (and used to it), you might not like this game however if you want to try something new then this game is worth a shot. This game has limited HUD, there is no minimap and if somebody is shooting, you will not be given a hint and you will need to find the source yourself. You will be given a compass to help you to locate yourself, and to give other people hints about the location of the enemy. Every single bullet counts, I mean 1-3 shots can kill somebody, do not spray and pray. You will not be given a hint about your location, so you need to be observant and check your surrounding.  One big problem about this game is.... There is no melee so you can't kill other players with a knife, it can be a huge turn off for some people (I am one of those people), nevertheless it is less likely that you will use melee in the game, it is most likely a gunfight.  If you want a shooter game and want to spice things up then Arma 3 could be the game for you, if you are still unsure then you can check some YouTube videos and see it for yourself. This game is hard, the control buttons are many (I highly recommend newcomers to go to the tutorial first) before going into the campaign or multiplayer.  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- My PC specs can be seen in my profile, just to let you know how well this game run at least in this setup. I can play this game in Ultra settings.

Updated review: I have been exploring more features of Arma 3 and I love it!   I have been playing a bit of the standard Arma 3 features which are fun, but the sheer number of mods and workshop missions is unreal! This game is so flexible.  My most favourite mods and missions I have been playing are:  Altis life: think along the lines of GTA, but everyone ever where is a real player, the police, military, bandits, civilians, criminals, everyone. It is a very immersive mission where you do what you want, whenever you want. Earn money through doing legal jobs, or become a criminal and traffic drugs, rob banks, rob other players, do whatever you want to survive, but beware your actions could get you on the police wanted list. Buy food, weapons, vehicles, licenses and so much more, it is a great experience when your on an active server.  Escape Altis: an online coop game which can also be played single player, your goal to escape the huge island of altis. You will encounter AI enemy`s in all kinds of locations, choose how you get through, stealthy? Or guns blazing? Do it your way! This mission is very challenging and lots of fun, best with mates!  Breaking Point: Think Dayz but on a bigger map, less glitches and now a choice of 5 factions to choose from. Each with their own perks, rules (or none depending which you choose), and appearance. Breaking point provides 5 maps, Altis, Stratis, Thirsk summer and Thirsk winter.  The thirsk maps are PvP orientated with survival thrown in for good measure.  Stratis is bigger than than Thirsk maps with a bigger focus on survival against zombies and other players. Altis is just huge!  While breaking point is still in its infancy, the dev team is working really hard at it and adding new features and maps frequently. Vehicles in this mod are fairly rare, so expect work to be done finding them, you will also have to fix them up to get them working to.  I love the Arma 3 engine, it is so flexible and allows for so many different ways to play, it just never gets dull.  I highly recommend it!

ArmA 3 is a sandbox military game, which excels in a number of ways. The way the game encourages community-play and user modification is unprecedented. I'll briefly summarize a couple pros and cons.  PROS:   Infinitely customizable. With the in-built editor and SQF scripting language, you can make any scenario you can think of.   Thriving modding community. With small mods that change minor gameplay aspects to complete overhauls like CUP and RHS, there is an incredible amount of community built content for you to enjoy.   Variety of scenarios. If you want to be a lone wolf in a zombie apocolypse, or just a standard rifleman in a huge coordinated operation, there are scenarios and groups for you.   CONS:   Almost requires DLC. You can play the game purely vanilla, but most servers and communites you find will require at least Apex, if not everything else.   Steep learning curve. Being a game with incredible movement controls, these controls all require keybinds that need to be learned, on top of potentially learning to fly planes and helicopters, this could take a while.   In summary, Arma 3 can cost a bit and take a large amount of hard drive space, but is extremely rewarding to learn and find a group of people to play with.

Having spent about 1,000 hours on Arma2/OA (between D2D/Disk Version/Steam) and 70 hours in Arma 3, it's no contest in anything but graphics. Arma2/OA is much better in terms of realism. The bullet sponge AI in Arma3 (sorry body armor doesn't let you just keep trucking like it was a bee sting) just kill any immersion whatsoever along with the ridiculous fantasy Iranian units. Also simple things like the 'flying' drop down when placing units are gone in the new editor for no apparent reason.  Overall Arma 3 does look a lot better, but still runs pretty poorly regardless of high end hardware (i7 960@4.1Ghz+STRIX R9 390X/ 3930K@4.2Ghz+STRIX GTX 1060/ i7 4770K@4.3Ghz+780Ti MATRIX SLI (previously 290X MATRIX CF and 390X STRIX CF) / i7 6700@stock+GTX 1070FE / i7 5930K@4.5Ghz+STRIX 980Ti SLI (previously 780Ti MATRIX SLI).   Rather than wasting time on a dubious futuristic setting it would have been far better for the developers to focus on quashing performance issues and providing a believable simulation with realistic damage based on impact point+round+angle. I see Arma 3 as a downhill slide for the series, being far more casual than previous iterations in terms of attempted realism compounded by unwillingness to expand the core mechanics for realism that had been laid down since OPFP. Hmm, where do I begin with this review?  Well, first of all, I am a veteran to this series and I have been playing ArmA for the past 6 years. This is a game that will always keep you interested with the powerful Eden Editor, Zeus, various multiplayer gamemodes and the brilliant singleplayer campaigns.  For the beginners, this is a game that you need to keep on playing to develop your skills, you will not start off as a hero or have the ability to 'run and gun.' This is a military combat simulator sandbox and if you get shot, chances are you will die but if you don't, your abilities will be hindered and become combat ineffective. Best way to learn how to play the game is to go into the editor and make your own little scenario to practise or use one of the many scenarios made by the developers. For multiplayer, there are many different types of gamemodes and missions available across hundreds if not thousands of servers around the globe but if you want a true immersive experience, you would need to join a unit or community that plays with operations, teamwork, coordination and more, including mods to get the best experience.  Mods; man, that's a huge part of the ArmA community. There is a massive community on the BiForums and Steam Workshop dedicated to modifications to enhance your ArmA experience. Some of the big ones like Community Upgrade Project (CUP) has a variety of weapons, vehicles and terrains ported from previous games to ArmA 3. Red Hammer Studios (RHS) has United States Armed Forces (USAF) which includes a large array of US units, weapons, ground vehicles and aircraft. There are so many mods that this game has that I could write a paper to list not even half of them.  The official DLC's for this game are quality content, the Marksman DLC and the Helicopter DLC are a little on the expensive side of things for the amount of content you get but APEX is the best DLC for this game, an entirely new map, lots of new weapons, vehicles, units and more. However I would still suggest you wait until this game and its DLC's go on sale before purchasing it, better 'bang for your buck.'

This is a 1st/3rd person war simulation engine, not quite a game on its own (yet). Arma III comes with very little content on its own and it is ripe with missing features and bugs, but the guys over at Bohemia Interactive have been dilligent with patches, features, and support (There's an entire website dedicated to live bug tracking and suggestions with feedback from the developers which is incredibly rare). That being said, many users still continually suffer from lag and crashes and the game has very high requirements to run and look nicely.   Despite the missing bugs and features, the game has all the core components of a strong simulation game. The developers have done well on bullet physics and the graphics look really nice on max. On the other hand, the game is very complex and the controls will be difficult to pick up for new players. Your bullets are not lazers that hit your target immediately, you will need to range your target, adjust the sight on your gun to the appropriate distance, and lead them appropriately to have a chance of hitting them. Unless you're under 300m away, then let your inner call of duty player out.   The game's built in content consists of scenarios and the recently added campaign. The scenarios and tutorials are introductions into the various attributes of the game from flying helicopters to assault diving to artillerty strikes. The campaign feels like a bunch of scenarios strung together and adds very little to the game. All things considered, the campaign is bad and you won't want to play or remember it for long.   But you don't buy this game for the single player.  The multiplayer game modes are what put this game head and shoulders above other similar multiplayer games. Players can join a wide variety of different game modes that are downloaded and installed automatically for the player before joining the server. There are only two maps: A large map that bogs down servers with its sheer size and a smaller map that doesn't bog down the servers as much. Just like in Arma 2, there are many guides, tools, and tutorials provided and created by the community in order to produce new and diverse game modes and content. The popular DayZ mod will likely not exist in Arma 3 because of the upcoming standalone installment, but the Wasteland mode offers the same scavenging/survival mechanics sans zombies. There are also deathmatches, missions, and rpg modes to cater to every type of player.   The Call of Duty crowd would probably get bored by the slow pace of the game. The Battlefield 4 crowd will have much more common ground, but might dislike the lack of polish in the game. The Arma 2 crowd will enjoy the game.  My tips for starting to play: In any game mode, in any lobby, in any situation where you're unsure, in any situation where you have no clue what's going on, ask questions. The community is incredibly responsive and helpful. They will know the game better than you and their help will mean the difference between all your shots going right over the enemy's head or right into the enemy's head (Adjust your scope's range with PgUp and PgDown).  You should probably stay out of global voice chat (Use . and , to change your chat channel, stick to the blue team channel if you're not sure where you should be talking).

When it comes to writing a review for this game, I really don't even know what to say. This series has always been a go to for me, basically since the beginning of my PC gaming days, I was playing OFP in 2001. Over the years this series has entertained me longer than any other i've ever played. There is absolutely no competition to ArmA, no game/simulator comes even close to what arma has to offer, or even comes close to the gameplay experience ArmA has. As any ArmA veteran knows, there is some humps you need to tackle to get use to the game. It's not a game a where you can just join a server and play like battlefield or red orchestra. That's not how the game is structured. It's not a game where you can play it natively, it is not designed in a structured gameplay style what-so-ever. This isn't a game where you can play by yourself( Well, you could...). It's hard to explain to the average-gamer what this game is about. It's a platform and if you're playing it without utilizing the very nature of the game is not going to result in the ideal experience you have heard about. You need to have a community of players, small or large, and 3rd party content to form the game into the GAME you want this PLATFORM to be. The average content pack is at least 10gb, but you should expect 20+gb of content. The game is designed to be modified. Arma 3 has no asset content and ArmA 2 is merely a skeleton of a game body. Explaining to the average player that they need to download a special program and install 10s of gigabytes of content is difficult, it sounds like hard work. Your average player doesn't want to 'work' to get the game into a playable state. That's understandable, but that's not what this game is about. It's so versatile for a reason, so groups of people can make the game exactly how they want it. It's really almost too much to explain, all I can say is that if you give this game a chance, and you put in the work for the first time around to set it up, it's amazing. It is absolutely unmatched. Almost every issue you are going to hear about this game comes down to user error. If people are complaining about the AI, and the futuristic content( or the lack of content), that is entirely because they are not using the game to it's potential. If you don't alter the game meant to be altered, you're going to have a bad experience. The same concept can be applied to performance. I'm sure if you've looked up ArmA, you're probably wondering if you can run it. It is true that arma is a heavy game to run, but that usually is not the source of the problem. 90% of the people complaining about lag are running the game on weak computers that just cannot run arma. The game is not considerably unoptimized, it does have some networking issues, but they are hardly the cause of any major performance problem. This is an intensive game, 5 years ago you could not even dream to see what arma is providing. In a couple years, it will be much more easy to run given the bound-to-happen advancements in hardware. It also comes down to the mission maker and the server hoster, if you don't run your servers right, you are going to give your players bad performance. This game does not babysit you, and you should not expect it to. If you know what you are doing, and you have a decent computer, you will run this game with no problem at all. I hope you take the time to try it, and don't blame everything you are uncapable to do on Bohemia. There is very few things I can say that have made an impact on my life that aren't real, maybe 1 other game out of the hundreds that i've played. ArmA is one of those, there is some great, hilarious experiences in ArmA that I think I will remember the rest of my real life. Not many games can do that.

This game isn't comparable to the simple minded Call of Duty, or Battlefield. It's much different, more complicated and dynamic, however that's what makes this game so ridiculously fun to play. The sheer diversity of this game, including mods and custom campaigns from Steam Workshop makes this game replayable for what seems an eternity.   ArmA 3 provides what ArmA 2 has, and even more, with better graphics, gameplay, controls and detail. Don't let the absurd metascore of 74/100 turn you away (Metacritic are idiots who only use 5 minutes of gameplay to rate a game, unless they're paid otherwise. Come at me Metacritic.) This game deserves much better reception than it has.  A solid game for a solid player, ArmA 3 will provide hours upon hours of entertainment for a first person shooter (or an RTS player) who are looking for a game that requires more skill and organisation to play.  Some of the best mods and game modes available for ArmA 3 are;  -Zeus (The official ArmA 3 RTS combat mode) combines an RTS experience from the eyes of a God, to the FPS experience from a player on the ground, adapting to dynamic situations created by the God.  -PLAYERUNKNOWN'S Battle Royale (Effectively the 'Hunger Games' of ArmA) Battle out over a small island, loot military camps and towns for weapons, and battle to the death as the game area gets smaller and smaller, last man standing wins!  -ArmA 3 Wasteland (Sandbox combat) Stockpile weapons, vehicles and aircraft, build your base with a team and battle between 3 factions with up to 80 players for control over airfields, bases, and objectives to win the game!  -Breaking Point (ArmA 3 DayZ) A zombie survival based off DayZ for the ArmA 3 maps - Stratis and Altis  and many others!  Do I recommend this game? Hell yeah I do.

This game.....This GAME.  Where do I start, I love the â¥â¥â¥â¥ out of this game, been trying to achieve MLG at BI's series for a long time now. I've played the Arma series since I was rekkin kids on A2 from 600 on Utes with my Ruski tool, holding a base right in the middle for a few hours every day. It's a beautiful and engaging experience, that leaves you on the edge of your seat, sometimes wishing you were holding your Grandma's face to squeeze tight (till she dies)... Tactical decisions are important, using the terrain and engaging with the movement structure of your enemies is a thrilling experience, adrenaline pulses as bullets and rockets fly closeby. You will never have to remember parts of maps (minute detail), as the maps on this are so big that it allows you to use your brain, instead of arena shooters which don't challenge the psyche.   Graphics - The original Arma 3 engine includes DX11 integration and standardised PhysX interactions, due to a new update recently the game has come to include Volumetric Lighting (big +), Upgraded textures (more vibrant), Water Refraction and a host of other improvements (60+ bug fixes - glaring bugs such as the offsight RPG Alamut Optic). The graphics second Terrain to Item models, however new improvements in the recent update have subsided these issues, Gear is of a signicantly high polycount as well as Vehicles.   ISSUES: Now I'm sure most of us have had a bad experience of Arma FPS lag. And for a long time now, BI has been using the BS excuse 'It's mods.'   Although partly true, that is actually a lie. The way Arma simulates enemies, its peer to peer network structure, animation timers and no multi-threading support are the real reasons behind the terrible frames of Arma 3.  This. Needs. To. Stop.  Although too late for an A3 release, A4 must leave these issues behind.  Gameplay - Arma 3 can be a deeply tactical and engaging game. Many complex systems entwine with each other to create as much of a realistic experience as possible, for example:  - 27 Hit boxes on overall model (from head to toe) - Multiple ammo types (ballistics, AP, EPR, special purpose ((need mods for some))  - Multiple types of vests (explosive resistant, harnesses, body armour, fba) - Multiple attachments (flashlights, scopes, silencers, laserlights) - Unique damage system that many call BS but is actually indepth af for example: Armour actually takes stress under duress, which creates a deeper and more realistic feel to armour. - Your gun can deflect bullets - Bullet penetration  Different types of team play are offered in Arma 3. From 2 - 80ppl, if you wish to be in a large group, there is one out there for you. Expanded group finding features such as the Squad pages and things such as Side chat to hook up with like minded people. There are several clans of varying sizes such as mine, however there are some humungous clans for the more mil sim oriented. Now here's the real thing that makes this stand out from other shooters, I think this is a big thing: anyone can be good at this game. All it takes is knowledge and sensibility when dealing with the sort of situations Arma 3 can spawn. Such as:  - Attacking a base of 14 people by yourself, watching as a chopper crash lands into the base, explosions and debris everywhere! Bodies and people flying to and fro.. - Singing Beyonce down your mic to someone before running out and blasting their head off - Your first RPG heli kill - Your first 9.3 heli kill - Your first 7.62 heli kill - Your first 5.56 heli kil- you get the idea! - One 7.62 to get a double kill on a moving vehicle - Lagging - Dying by rocks - Lagging - Dying by terrain glitches -Lagging  Everything from Capture the Flag to Zombie mods. A favourite of mine is Sa-Matra WS, a very good mod indeed! The varying game modes and the sandbox aspect of Arma 3 really engages the community and attracts newcomers! This game can be completely different dependent on which mod you play. However many of these can easily corrupt which leaves some users unable to resolve issues.   GLARING ISSUE: Horrendous desync issues have plagued Arma 3 since its inception, these have prevented any serious types of eSports leagues. This is a detrimental experience to gameplay, and you will run into it constantly you will get killed by lag constantly and if you are okay with this buy the game, if not DO NOT BUY THIS GAME EVER. (Wait till Arma 4)   Ergonomics - UI in Arma 3 has never been a problem with Bohemia taking a down-to-earth approach to UI design, clearcut menu's, expanded Map features such as markers, topography etc.   Mod support has been vastly expanded with a server browser that is noob friendly, a launcher that highlights and patches missing files and full Steam Workshop support. This is a 10/10.   Finally let me just sum up the experience you will get from this game. If you're looking for sophisticated group play, come to Arma, you'll find a group of weary game travellers such as yourself, who know there â¥â¥â¥â¥ and can provide you with some irreplicable entertainment. Beware of lag and FPS issues, these are the two things hold this game back from a 9/10 or 10/10. It is my favourite game but it is still very imperfect.   Final Verdict: 8/10

I am very, very conflicted while writing this review. I really loved playing Arma 3. I've had some good times and made some good memmories. And I still havn't even fully explored all the mods that are available! But like I said, I'm conflicted. And here's why.   -No Real Solo Play Online   If you plan on playing alone, prepare to not have fun. Unless you're a gaming golden god with the reaction speed of a gerbil on speed, and the skills of a pro, you're going to be â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ off a lot. Especially in specific mods that pit you against other players (Wasteland etc.), you will get angry. Playing mods like this you really shouldn't be someone who gets attached to anything, and is basically entertained by anything that goes beyond finding things go 'boom' interresting. If you want to spend quality time, find a MilSim group. But you'll have to spend a good amount of time on ArmA 3 figuring things out, and also trying to actually get INTO a MilSim group.   -The Single Player Campaign   While I found it fairly entertaining, certain points get tedious and annoying. Especially since the AI have special eyes that can see you from 2KM away as if you were 2M away. But all in all; it's a decent campaign to go through once. (quite lengthy too with about 5 or 6 hours on average.)  I don't know if it can be counted as SP, but the Eden editor can be really fun to play around in! Getting actual things done, and making a working MP map is a huge challenge though. It will take many, many hours to get a MP map working and onto the steam workshop!   -The Community   Ehm, how do I put this... The community is... different. While it has the internet classics such as rage kids and memelords, it contains a more rare breed of internet personality; the elitist. Don't be fooled by people saying that the community is mature, because of it's learning curve and MilSim niche-ness. Personally, I find the elitism to be the most annoying part about Arma 3. The players who find the need to rub in their kills. The players who have the humility of a peacock. Which also brings me to the last group of people I'll talk about; the die-hards. We all know them. People who have 2000 hours logged in Arma 3 and eat, breathe and probably excrete Arma. While I don't really have anything against them (They're better then me. Oh well.) but it does get frustrating when you have people that are making their tea and at the same time headshot you from 3KM distance.    Ratings    + Delivers a MilSim game + A decent amount of equipment variety. + Loads and loads of good mods. + Group fun! ;) + The game is pretty stable in my experience. (Bug wise)  +/- Community can sometimes be frustrating. +/- The game itself can get quite frustrating. (unless like I mentioned, you're MLG pro JesusFPS.) +/- Steep learning curve to not-scrubness.  - Requires a lot of time to actually get into the more MilSim multiplayer parts.    Summary    Pretty gud gam. Buy.

There is a Soviet joke from early 80s that goes like this:  Moscow, summer morning, Sheremetyevo airport.  A representative of some very successful Japanese tech corporation heads back to his homeland after an official visit to USSR during which he observed the technological feats of Soviet people. Of course, a huge delegation of Party leaders and reporters is present, just like during any other event of this sort. So, as he walks to his plane, he becomes surrounded by reporters and they ask him, 'What have you liked the most about Soviet Union?'. â You have great children, they're so playful, happy and optimistic about their future. â Awesome! - reporters reply - and have you liked anything else? â You have great children. â Yeah, we love our children too, but what about our cars and TVs and fridges and roads and other things? â You have great children - the representative replies - but everything you make with your hands is terribly bad.  So, Arma series has a really great community. An amazing one, really. I'm thoroughly convinced that no other game has a similar one. But everything made by Bohemia Interactive...  Well, it's not exactly  terribly  bad (and at times it's quite good actually) but Arma, in a way, carries the spirit of Soviet Union's industry: a single manufacturer that gets most of its revenue from excellent military products also produces various civilian goods. These goods, however, while being suitable for their purpose, have a mediocre quality, especially compared to the products of Western companies. But it's the only manufacturer in the country and the Iron Curtain is still in place so you don't really have a choice but to recommend these products to your family and friends.  You really like that Mercedes-Benz W123? Well, too bad, here's a ticket for UAZ-496, comrade.   You're #47,254,875 in the queue.

When you're not getting killed by a door or suffering from 10 FPS on your Â£3000 Ultra-Advanced Gaming PC, this game offers a lot of fun through semi-realistic combat and a wide range of game modes.   Multiplayer is what makes the game. Offline game modes are mainly used for practice as the campaign is pretty basic in story and character detail. However, it's hard to get bored of everything that multiplayer has to offer; Altis Life RPG, Wasteland, Exile, Invade & Annex, you name it.   The gameplay mechanics are the worst part of the game. You really can die by opening a bloody door, albeit rare. Not to mention the driving physics. It can be very tough to drive using just W, A, S and D. Even crashing into a rock that appears as though it just 'Came outta nowhere!' at 5MPH can do severe damage to your car and health. The game's packed with glitches.   Aside from the occasional buggy annoyance, if you're looking for a war simulator that allows a range of unique experiences, ARMA 3 is probably your best bet.

This is NOT COD, it actually takes time effort to learn how to hit a target with an assault rifle at 300 meters.  Fatigue actually has an effect on the game, you have to stop and catch your breath if you move too fast for the weight you caring if you want to actually hit anything. The enemy AI is intelligent, they actually get into cover when being shot at, and they have great accuracy when returning fire.  You can move freely in between infantry and mechanised roles, without loading screens. The numbers of each on you team actually have a big effect on the outcome, as well as how they are used, as most vehicles require multiple players to use them effectively, e.g. A tank needs a gunner driver and a commander to be effective.  Arma 3 improves greatly on Arma 2, and with over 300 hours spent between them I can defiantly say this game is worth buying

Age of Empires 3  Genre: Strategy - Real Time Strategy Rating: 10/10 Personal playing period: 5+ years Is it worth a buy: Yes. Even at full price. This is a necessity for any strategy players collection. Girl vs Game: Unless it's some super model I'd definately rather play the Game.  Personal Comment: This is an amazing game with endless amounts of game time. The hours on here isnt a fraction of my actual game time online and offline. Been playing this game since the day it was released and still play it and love it today. I even missed a couple of meals as well as toilet breaks playing this believe it or not. I have bladder and bowel control of a ninja thanks to AOE.  Online gaming: The online gaming community is still very active and people of all skill levels are on it. You will find anywhere between 500 to 2000 people online at any given time. Beware though that even though AOE is helpful and awesome the online community are sometimes a bunch of cocktonsil nimrod supremists who think they're amazing whilst never having seen or felt a girl up close unless in a magazine. But if your skin is thick and you dont give a flying **** about other people you'll be fine.  Short Summary: This is a real time strategy game that plays off in the medieval times. There are 8 standard civilizations, 3 native indian civilizations and 3 Asian civilizations. Each civ provides a different set of advantages and it takes time to learn how to utilise the various civs to their full capability. Learning each civilisation takes time and it is great fun doing that. There are countless amounts of maps that allow for the use of different strategies. The game also has a story rich single player campaign. I have not played the campaign yet but never felt the need to as the standard game modes offer more than enough fun and game time. The game also has progressive improvement meaning the more you play the more items get unlocked and the stronger your civilisation becomes. This ensures that you want to play more and more in order to improve the strength of your favourite civilisation.  Learning Curve and Gameplay: Easy to start but tough to master. The learning curve to start playing and learning the basics is very easy. Learning the various civilisations and their strengths is more challenging and may take a lot of practice and time. The gameplay is very simplistic in it being a basic RTS with click and place. Gathering of basic resources and using those resources are easy and self explanotary. A tutorial can be played to understand the basics but this game is very playable and a new player will get it after playing only for a few hours.

Experiences with helicopters:  Very first game: Get in small chopper with five guys and fly for about six minutes to meet a contact. Upon reaching him, I promptly shot him as I didn't see a nameplate.  Some time later: Get in back of dual rotor troop transport with ~6 other troops. Get near LZ, high power shot passes through the hull behind my head, whistles past me and wrecks my SL who was briefing us on the mission.  Several days later: Time to try the pilot class. What could go wrong? I task myself with evacing a small squad on the ground under heavy enemy fire. I get about a kilometer away, when enemy AA takes out my engine and some other fancy control things. With what I could control, I maneuvered around while trailing black smoke calling MAYDAY over the group chat. I hit the ground hard, somehow still intact, and grind along the terrain for at least a hundred meters, tearing my rotor off on a nearby tree and hitting a few enemy soldiers during the powerslide. I crawl out of the wreckage barely alive, and talk through the radio to reassure them that I survived. I then hear the ground team over the radio saying that their mission was now a rescue op. To them, they saw a helo closing in to land, only to crash in the most violent way possible, pretty much cutting a path to me. They made it just as I got shot up.    Bravo Squad's final stand: This happened earlier today and had my heart pounding, our ten man squad was deployed in the open completely surrounded by enemies. Within seconds of disembarking, enemy fire cut down a few of us, who we were forced to leave up on the hill. We all scrambled down in different directions to find tiny pieces of cover while we waited for our attack chopper to open fire. He did, but was promptly hit and crash landed a quarter mile away. With our remaining men, we moved down the valley toward the wreckage, finding him incapacitated next to the cockpit. On a quick head count, we found that our combat medic had been killed in the opening wave and we had no way to save him in the field. While our SL called for a medevac, I picked up the pilot and pulled him into a small house, which we quickly garrisoned. By this time, we were down to five of our original team, plus one of our own wounded and the pilot. Our requests for a medevac quickly turned into an extraction request, which was accepted by a pilot nearly 10km away.  We held for several minutes, until we started to hear the chopper getting close to our position. My SL had been shot in the face through a window, along with our marksman. The incoming pilot essentially told us that we had ten seconds after he touched down to get on board or he would have to leave. Aware of this, I picked up the heli pilot, an engineer picked up our SL, and our other autorifleman followed behind us, giving covering fire. the engineer reached the chopper. loaded our SL into the back and jumped in, giving supporting fire. I reached the chopper next, and just as I got the pilot inside, a shot hit me in the back and incapacitated me. Our rifleman turned to me, and in that moment got shot in the arm.  He just yelled at our pilot to go, the fire was too much to stay. Not even five seconds after dustoff, an enemy sniper caught him.  You could say I'm enjoying the game.

Arma 3 is one of those games you hate, but you still play it because it is so good.  Arma 3 is unique in how it plays out but without doubt has some flaws. A common problem is optimization; this problem is a big one considering if you would like to play on a server with a decent amount of players, you will be ploughed down to 30 frames per second or below. It can be a horrible experience. However, with the right tweaks to the game you can easily run it at 100 fps+ (in singleplayer) with decent specs (if you would consider a 560 ti and i5 3570 as somewhere between good and bad). I suspect that the framerate problem on servers may because how the Arma server is designed, but that is for bohemia to improve.  For out this Arma 3 is a brilliant designed game in the manner that pretty much everything you'll find on the server browser is user made. To the extent where a mod or mission may completely overcome the 'Military simulator' aspect of the game. At one point I even found a mod where you played as a robot car war machine, just like that old tv show with the bots fighting in an arena.   If you are into tactics and survival, wasteland might be the place for you, with the constant feeling of being watched by someone with a very big weapon, while attempting to gear up so you can fight back. Alternatively, the great feeling of wiping a 5-man squad purely based on your skill and intelligence, by outplaying them. If you are into big battles, king of the hill is something you may like. With giant battles going on, including infantry, armoured cars, and air support. Even if these things are not for you, Altis life might be. With the biggest (or one of the biggest) player-base in Arma, the incredible Altis life is really something in its own. You start out by being a civilian with nothing, where you get to choose a path of Justice as a police officer, medic or something alike. Alternatively, if you strive after being the biggest drug lord on the server by harvesting crops and processing them into drugs to sell. On the other hand, if you simply just want to pluck apples for a little cash you can do that as well. For you Garryâs mod veterans, this is pretty much the DarkRP of Arma.  And if none of these are something that you'd spend time playing, why not grab a text editor and start scripting a mission exactly how you'd want it!  Though I recommend this game, I would like to point out that it is not that fun to play alone; you definitely need some friends to play with.

I'm gonna get slammed for this review, but you know me:  Arma 3 was recommended to me by a mutual friend at the time, so I looked into it, as well as insisting to pay $60 'the price of a full game' for a shooter that was released over 2 years ago.   I thought I would be amazed with Arma 3... I wasn't.  First strike, I was met with poor optimization and horrendous frame rate issues, even with the terrible looking standard graphics the maximum frames I could only achieve 27. I can already hear everyone shouting 'You're PC is trash! Git gud, Stealth...Poorass.' I will have you know that this is quite the machine I have with an AMD Radeon R7 370 Graphics.  Arma 3's single player offering is a joke. It's worse than Star Wars Battlefront EA singleplayer. After the first mission I just stopped. But then I tried Arma's multiplayer, what the game is praised for. Now I do respect that Arma 3 is supposed to be one of the most realistic military shooters on the market. But perhaps its a bit... too realistic... You're going to spend more time walking with your squad from point A to point B, getting lost and checking your map and compass often alot more than actually fighting in the game.- I've only been in 1 firefight. I would take Battlefield over Arma any day.   I was going to rate Arma 3 a 5. But gets held back to a 4/10 due to it's poor optimization, terrible AI, and dull gameplay.  This was my first refund on Steam and I couldn't be happier to get my full $60 back.  That's gonna do it for Arma 3 and I will see you on the next review. Let's form up! ~Stealth 1548
