The most comprehensive military sim out there, setting you loose on a massive island with all of the weapons, vehicles and scenarios you could possibly wish for.  The game itself has remained almost unchanged since the original Operation Flashpoint, released over 10 years ago. However, of all the iterations, Arma 3 is the one that has improved things the most. These aren't big changes, but merely small gameplay tweaks that make it feel more polished and smooth.  Graphically, it's convincing. It isn't always beautiful but it gets the atmosphere of a real place just right and the large view distances are key to making it feel ALIVE. You can tell that the developers did their homework when researching the island that this game is based on (Yup, it is a real place).  If you don't know anything about this game, the best word to sum it up with would be 'realistic'. You are a single soldier in a large, real-time conflict. You can die from a single bullet or stray shell and alone you have limited influence over how the battle will go. Expect to be crawling through muddy fields or cowardly hiding behind cover as bullets whiz overhead. Don't expect to behave like Rambo and to survive.  I wouldn't consider this game 'complete' just yet- for months they have been rolling out updates and patches and at the time of writing, the main campaign is only 1/3 released. That being said, it's the community that really supports this game. Mods like Dayz show how flexible and open-ended the game can be. Really, Arma 3 can be seen as offering an island and great multiplayer support, letting the community come up with the best content.  Personally, I haven't spent much time in the large-scale multiplayer side of things. I prefer playing missions with a friend and those experiences have been enjoyable and memorable. Expect a single objective to take a while and for it to get rather frustrating as you die through seemingly no fault of your own. I've also spent a lot of time simply exploring the large island. Yup, on my own, with no NPCs or other players. I love the sights and sounds. I love exploring over the next mountain, or lounging about on a beach, soaking up the digital rays. I don't expect other people to find that fun and neither does the game- the fantastic mission editor simply opens up countless opportunities for you and I chose one of the most dull and mundane simply to see how much enjoyment I could extract from it.  The community is what makes this product what it is. They're serious but loyal and will likely be playing this game for years to come. You'll make good friends if you behave in a sensible and team-worthy fashion and thanks to the Steam workshop support there are thousands of mods and maps to download to boost the number of scenarios the game has to offer.  Buying this game is an investment. The developers and community have pledged their loyalty to build it into a must-have title, though it could take several years to reach that stage. Don't expect gameplay that's easy to jump in to, nor should you expect a fun standalone experience. But this game is no COD. By default it's not a mainstream game, but the possibilities it offers you are almost endless.

I can't say enough good things about ARMA 3. This is a game for someone who wants a truly lifelike military sandbox. This is not COD or BF; for the most part, run and gun tactics will only get you shot and killed here. You will have to think quickly and thoroughly to plan your assaults, escapes, etc. You will die a lot initially until you learn how to properly strategize and utilize the assets at your disposal but you will have fun doing it.   The Bohemia content is a blast to play and replay but where this game really shines is in the wealth of community created content that offers something for everyone. The level editor makes it easy to create your own scenarios and tailor missions to your specific desires and play styles. Truth be told I would pay the $60.00USD for this game just to play the Breaking Point mod (think DayZ using Arma3 engine/maps) but either way, the game was well worth the money.

I parachute into a hot zone. I hear the distant crackle of small arms fire. Kind of like fireworks. 4th of July... I snap out of it as the ground suddenly rushes up and meets me. I roll onto my stomach and crawl into a nearby bush. I jumped with 3 squad mates. Where are they? I glance around. One comes drifting down dead in his harness. The other is nowhere to be found. Tension builds in my belly as the chatter of nearby automatic weapons fire starts back up again. I gaze cautiously out into the outcropping of squat buildings ahead.   Is that where the fire is coming from? I can't tell. Can't be sure.  I am frozen.   There is a house across the street. The street is narrow. I could dash for it. But it might blow my cover. 50 meters never looked so far in my life. I get into a crouch. Glance around again. Suddenly I see smoke rising from a dusting of rocks to my left. I immidiately drop down and toss a grenade. It works, the enemy tango dashes from the rocks. A few swift pops and he's down. Was he alone?   There was no way to know for sure.   This is warfare. This is Arma.

If you haven't heard of Age of Empires, then say hello to one of the most iconic RTS franchises. With the release of Age of Empires 2 HD Edition, there's quite a bit to go around for fans of the franchise. But enough about that, how is Age of Empire 3?  Well it really depends on what you're after. Visually, it's still pretty freaking gorgeous, and it holds up quite well, though it does show its age a bit (what do you expect for an 9 year old game). the lighting effects are great, and the smoke and particle effects, especially the destructible debris that falls of buildings is a nice visual treat, and I remember how amazing it looked back in 2005, and to me it still looks great.  In terms of gameplay, it feels more in line with Age of Mythology, Ensemble's previous entry, rather than Age of Empires. From the way you choose a leader each age (mirrors choosing minor deities in Age of Mythology) to general UI layout and control schemes, AoE3 feels much like a spiritual successor to Age of Mythology, with a focus on historics rather than mythos.   Though with this iteration of the series, there are new, much needed improvements. Gone is the need for a drop off point for your workers; like the Atlantean race in AoM:TT (Age of Mythology: The Titans), your workers only need to mine from the resource to generate that resource. This makes macromangement considerably less fiddly.   Another change is how Caravans work in AoE3; instead of building a market, creating some caravans, and sending them to a Town Centre, there are now neutral Trading Posts that need to capture, which provide a steady steam of either Wood, Gold, Food or Experience. There are other neutral buildings the map, such as native settlements, or saloons which give you access to new units.   But by far the biggest addition to the series is the Home City. The Home City has a deck of shipment cards which can be sent to you during the game, depending on how many levels you gain through experience (gained by fighting, find treasure, building or from aforementioned trade caravans). The shipments can range from dozens of cavalry soldiers, supplies of wood/gold/food, to permanent improvements to military, defense, economy and so on. It can change how you play, and it's an interesting additon to the game.  The singleplayer in the Complete Collection offers up plenty of content, with about 8 campaigns, ranging from 15th/16th Century colonials to Battle at Little Bighorn, to the Indian Revolution, and even a little bit in Japan during the Sengoku period. It has plenty of nicely realised characters, interesting stories for each campaign, and enough content for each campaign so they don't feel short. This along with the 14 civilizations you can play in singleplayer (and multiplayer, though there isnt much of a population) skirmishes means plenty of content for your money's worth.   If you're new to the Age of Empires franchise or if you enjoyed Age of Mythology, then Age of Empires 3 will be a fun ride through some events through history. If you preferred Age of Empires 2, then you might not like Age of Empires 3 quite as much. For me though, its a hearty recommendation.

Ah the good ol' Arma III. Lets get started.  Arma, a mil-sim game by Bohemia, how is it played? Custom game modes. Yes, there's a campaign, yes you can do the mil-sim related tasks and wage war against other mil-sim players, but this game isn't typically played like that. Custom maps like: Altis Life, King of the Hill, Battle Royale Mod, etc are how most people end up playing and enjoying this game.  As of this writing I play this game, for the most part, once or twice a week, but as you can see I've logged hundreds of hours on this game. That should speak quite a bit in regards to the fun factor. Whether you want to Role-Play with other players (who 50/50 just shoot anyways), play a giant game of king of the hill with big guns and vehicles, or just play an hour long survival last man standing kind of game... Arma III offers it.  Downsides to this game, bugs, lots of them, expensive DLC, and one of the most poorly optimized games I've ever played. The game would greatly benefit from a way more optimized engine that doesn't tank a modern PC under 60FPS by just being in a town.   Once again, that said, you can spend hundreds of hours entertaining yourself in the world that is Arma and I do highly reccomend this game for all shooter fans.

I have spent a good amount of time in this game, both singleplayer and multiplayer. And I have to say, this game can literally become any game you want. = Obviously, Arma 3 is built for epic tactical action gameplay. The base game involves around military atmosphere: tanks, attack jets, attack boats, armored cars, soldiers and helicopters; all of those can be accessed right away after you purchase the game and install it. = The game has many complicated systems and machanics, such as, commanding the AIs (it's a real pain in the butt), seats in vehicles, stances, movements, interaction menu, etc. This is why many new players feel disencouraged and quit playing the game. But if you are a tough gamer and able to deal with difficulties, then this game might be for you. = As I said earlier, you can experience this game in unlimited number of ways, with or without mods. Mods play a big role in the game, but I will say about that later. = Without mods, the player can still join several multiplayer servers, both PVP and PVE, which has different gamemodes too. But if you want to play singleplayer, this game can serves you well too. = Singleplayer in this game has 3 forms: campaign, scenarios, and editor. -Campaign is pretty much self-explainatory. You play as a soldier on the island with your fellow army teammates and go on an adventure with wide-open levels and a simple set of story. You can play the original Arma 3 base game's campaign or the ones you download from Steamworkshop (or others) which are user-created and some of them are really enjoyable to try out. -Scenarios are short Arma 3 missions that, usually, made by Arma 3 players and can be downloaded from the Steamworkshop (or other Arma 3 community websites) Some of them are really enjoyable like custom campaigns. -Editor is a very powerful tool in Arma 3. In this mode, you can create your own mission in any style you like. as long as you know how to do it. I suggest going through the Arma 3 editor guides and Arma 3 community websites to learn more about the editor. = MODS Mods are the wheels that keep this game running. There are countless of them and a lot of them can improve your overall experience in the game, some can change the game completely. For example, the mod 'Altis Life' is a multiplayer total conversion mod. It features the role-playing multiplayer experience, from normal civilians to police forces and outlaws. Therefore, even if you prefer a role-playing multiplayer game, you can play this game, just with mods. But if you are here to be a soldier on the battlefield fighting bad guys with fellow soldiers, you also have a lot of windows for modding. Weapon mods, vehicle mods, faction mods, etc. can be downloaded via Steamworkshop (and other websites) to add unlimited variety of reallistic content to the game. = MilSim MilSim stands for Military Simulation which, in the context of this game, is a style of gameplay that involves around serious and reallistic gameplay. Every player will act like a real life soldier and work together as a team. Usually, MilSim servers have mods to make the game more challenging and reallistic and admins of the servers or the head of the army will only pick players who are old enough and can play appropriately in their servers. So far, MilSim gameplay is the most accurate experience that Arma 3 is trying to offer to the players. = Thank you for reading the review. Graphics up pretty much full, played it and had an average framerate more than 30FPS, so all is good. I have a little play of single player and start to pick it up. Game looks great. Few Km of open sandbox.Can't complain.  I try joining a server. Stratis Wasteland. 70 players, smaller map then the main one. (19.3km or something i think). Spawn in and streight away i head some explosions and firing. Luckily enough on my first go online, i managed to take out the two guys firing and loot a vehicle. Nice rifle and a nightstalker scope. I just sat in a bush, my sights scimming around and taking out the odd players 1 by 1. Night time comes, Change scope to thermals. Beautiful. Hiding up a hill, sat in a bush, with a thermal scope and another 2 clips if ammo to use. I felt how sadistic i had become. Beautiful.  This was just wasteland mode. However there are many other modes. Altis RP i would say is the most populated. A role play island where a player will need to gain licenses, buy weapons, vehicles. Basically it's what GTA online would be like. I reccomend picking up some scenarios from the workshop, such as Whole lotta altis and whole lotta stratis. as we as some of the mission generators.  If you're amazing at CoD. Don't expect to be amazing at this. This is a real game and does require a lot of skill and thought. No running in expecting to kill 30 in a row.

I gave this a shot over the free weekend and here's what I learned:   1. You need an incredibly modern and powerful gaming PC to run attractive graphics with this. My system is 5 years old, 570 GTX can barely run this at the lowest graphics settings possible, and that's barely getting 30 fps.   2. The amount of key mapping you need to do to make this even somewhat manageable as a 'game' is insane. Basically, you need one of those 7 or 9 button gaming Mice, because you won't have enough sensible keyboard key locations to cover all of the crap.   3. For a game where voice communication is extremely necessary, the voice comm functionality in this game is quite limited, but that's not really an issue because everyone is going to be using TS3 anyway...   4. Good luck finding a decent server to play on. Most of them are run by fascist bronys. Others are run by incompetent admins and you can count on getting spawnkilled by your own team over and over until you leave and find a different server. No, I'm not kidding.   5. The game isn't worth 60 dollars. The rest of the game (that's right, you don't actually get the whole game for 60 dollars, you need all of the DLC too because the only good weapons are locked) is going to run you even more. So it's over $100 game that isn't worth playing unless you have a $2,500 computer and a $120 mouse.   6. It seems like, if you met all of the requirements above, the game *could* be enjoyable. Just know what you are really getting yourself into...

Arma 3 is a well made next game in the Arma series with many options you can do. Now I played many different modes and mods that I should give you a decent review about this game.  Story  I do know that there are not many people that want to buy Arma 3 because of the story, but it still has one and isn\'t bad. It is a new story and does not have something to do with Arma 2 or else. The story starts with a mission for you and another soldier to help out another Camp, but on youÂ´re way there an invasion of the AFF starts over the hole Island and you and youÂ´re superior that is with you at that time try to get to a safe place to reform their allies. This getÂ´s harder than though because the AFF troops are anywhere but helpfully there were some units from the UK that helps out and you can regroup with them and so the story starts where you try to get connected to another safe Island and do many different tasks.  Gameplay   You can control land sea and air craft vehicles or go by you\'re own foot on the maps Stratis or Altis and many modded maps. There is not rally a task given to you by the game, besides the story, there are many different tasks given to you by community made co-op missions or PvP modes and also the complete different thing like a real life in modes like good known \'Altis Life\'. But besides Altis Life or other similar mods this is a military simulation game and give you many possibilities to let it feel like that. In co-op missions in a group of friends you need to make a briefing of the situation and make a plan or just go on patrol and get surprised by an attack of an opposite fraction and many more kind of situations. There are too many different gameplay methods given to you by the community that I can not listen them all up here.  Pros: -maybe one of the best military simulation games so far -many and sometimes comepletly different kind of gameplay methods -good graphics  -game gets upadatet by the developers to fix bugs and make the game just better -active community -Steam Achievements -you can use the terrain to your advantage  Neutral: -KI is okay as an enemy in co-op missions and is not completely stupid but also not perfect right now  Cons: -hard to remember all the keys for new beginners -many bugs(like falling trough some stairs and die or looking trough a wall) -the game has FPS problems like FPS drops   Conclusion: This game has many good things to offer and is one of the most realistic games so far (especially with mods), but it still needs to get patched and fix bugs. Arma 3 is a game you should buy because of the game play you will not have in any game I know right now and you get to live with the bugs and learn to avoid them as much as possible and if you have friends to play with this game can get you many hours of fun game play to get.

Great gameplay, great visuals, sounds, and the two new islands are frankly wonderful and huge. In my opinion the most noticeable improvement since Arma 2 is that we are now evolving into some realistic and visually credible open world, as opposed to the narrow places kinda looking like more or less similar 'checkpoints' in previous games. The gameplay adjusts extremely well to the new terrains, making Arma 3 something closer to an actual simulation than 'just' an advanced FPS with 'milsim' elements into it. However, it is impossible to talk honestly about Arma 3 without telling what hurts most: the lack of vehicles (planes notably, but not only), the lack of weapons and few annoying Ai pathfinding issues (sometimes even on places where all should normally go well).  That being said, I personally can see an insanely great potential behind Arma 3, and the way it will continue to evolve will in my opinion probably make it simply one of the best game ever created. All it needs is some more time to grow up.

This is a very immersive game, with high attention to detail and a seemingly limitless amout of possibilities. Every peice of your gear is changeable... i mean sh*t you can run around the battlefield in nothing but your underwear and a t-shirt if you so please. You can change your camo and helmet and LBV and backpack and every other thing you carry. Everything that is in your inventory can be dropped or moved from bag to LBV or pants/ shirt pockets(and vice-versa). It provides a very similar experience to hardcore milsim airsoft (if thats what you're into... I am into airsoft) without the 'Hey call your hits' or 'Hey are you dead' BS. You are even able to create your own missions somewhat easily with the in-game mission editor. Anyway I figured I'd share one of my most memorable experiences in any operation in Arma- or any game out there.    I was playing on a mission that I created on Stratis(One of the in game maps). I was leading a 10 man assault on Air Station Mike 26. We were all riding in an APC. My gunner was doing great taking out ground troops, and even took out an Ifrit or two. Out of nowhere an enemy hit the APC we were in, popping all left side tires, stoping it dead in its tracks. I immidiately got out and threw a smoke grenade to either side and told my men to disembark. Unfortunately only 2 men made it out before the APC exploded. In that same explosion the 2 men that had made it out were killed. worried, I threw one more smoke grenade and waited for the smoke plume to build and ran straight back behind a small hill, dodging what seemed like the bullets from 1000 angry hostiles. Once behind the hill I healed my self, and radioed in for a helicopter extraction. I waited and waited until the heli showed up. All I could hear above me were the screams of the miniguns that the 2 door gunners were operating, and the swooping of the rotor. The heli flew right over my head and began to circle around the base, taking out enemy after enemy. I knew the helicopter would not last long, as it was simply a helicopter meant for extraction, and not any sort of combat, so I called in an attack heli for some added assistance. After the attack heli started to engage targets I sprinted inside the base behind a large H-barrier. I could see lots of enemies. I quickly engaged one enemy and started to advance to another H-barrier when I was hit. I quickly went prone and healed up, and threw my last smoke grenade inside the base. After about 10 seconds of letting the smoke build I ran up to a building and began to take out target after target, in some sort of spec ops manner(Yeah I was that good). I ran around the base with the supressive fire of the helicopters and cleared the entire base of any threat. After I called in the evac heli and flew myself back to base because the pilot was killed on landing because my area clearing is garbage. It was quite the experience to get the juices flowing.    This game never fails to impress, and I still find myself learning new things about it every day.

This game is really quite good. It wholly deserves the 60 dollar price in my opinion, and that is true to form. There has been a huge amount of work put into the game. Its scale and the seriousness with which it was handled by its developers absolutely deserves them the full 60 dollars. This game puts even next gen games to the test. It is fantastic. I will relay some of my experiences with the game:  Personally I am a HUGE fan of the lighting in the game. The dark is really dark, and the light is really light. The light is in fact just beautiful. There is nothing like driving in the night with your headlights on, and stopping somewhere with the light of your headlights to work by. Or moving through the dark in the morning, with a flashlight and a lighthouse far above you to keep things clear. Even tracers are quite well done, and you will constantly be taken aback by the absolute beauty and accuracy of both the lighting and the environment.  On to the environment. The environment is enormous. Hills, plains, farmland, valleys. It is all very well designed and is covered by very accurate and realistic looking flora which all server the purpose of providing some very useful and much needed cover. The scale of things is just huge, and is enough to blow ones mind. It is really something, standing on a hill 1 km away from an enemy platoon on the face of another and exchanging fire. That is what battle is, and that is really the scale that stands true to the test as what Arma is really about.  The vehicles are also a great part of the game, they are all EXTREMELY meticulously designed, and appear to be very much the real thing. In some ways, different, but you will not mind your long commutes via chopper or land solely because of the eye candy that is your ride.  The gunfire is a bit disappointing, however. Firing ones gun is not as much a pleasure as it may be in other games. It does not convey the same detail or intricate beauty that other parts of the game do, and does not feel nearly so powerful. I am not sure as to why this might be, but the guns are just so... light. I would like to see some more impressively realistic muzzle flare and gun interaction.  Additionally, the AI in the game is very flawed and can certainly leave one disappointed, especially during showcase missions. When I would like to play with a fully interactive AI, I meet soldiers who are completely unresponsive, downright born with autism and having a heart attack, or are just altogether far too quick to respond and accurate, just like a robot. The AI opponents often leave one shaking their head at the huge holes in interactability, especially on missions where otherwise this would be the focus of the game.  In total, however, the game is huge. If you are interested in the sort of fully fledged MILSIM combat that this game has to offer, please get it. I assure you that there is nothing else like this out there, and this is a game of its own. The creators had a mission, and that mission was achieved. Be responsible when you are flying your intricately designed helicopters or blazing tracer rounds at enemy soldiers down the ravine. Its fun stuff, and you never know where that may lead.

A follow up to the 2'nd Age of Empires that everyone loved.   Among many this game is not so good, some things were simplified, such as gathering resources - now there are 3 instead of 4 of them and your villagers don't have to come back to the lumberjack or the city centre to store them.  Many smaller tweaks and adjustments, and of course a heavy focus on musket fights, artillery and the transition from Renaissance to the Industrial Revolution and father away into the 19'th Century.   It's a shame that there weren't any additional elements added to the Steam release of the game.  Controls being one of the more touchy ones. For instance, to change the hotkeys you need to manually go through each tab. There is also no Steam Cloud, but they did add Trading Cards so that's one interesting thing to look forward to.  This game is soon to have 10 years after it's release. But this edition is by far the best one yet. You get all the expansions. Working multiplayer with a community that still lives. And of course that same old strategy many remember and honor as 'one of the best'.   The modest presentation of it's ancestors passed away. I'd say that the magnificence of the soundtrack itself says a lot:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7EWfMfHlFck&list=PL37F10A7ECDC81CA0&index=9   A Musical score composed by Ensemble Studios musicians Stephen Rippy and Kevin McMullan.   If History is of any interest to you, if the New World conquests were something you're keen on. Buy this game, especially when on sale!

One Word for this Game:G-R-E-A-T  How many hours does a normal EA title entertain you for like 60-70 Bucks? 5-8 hours, maybe 10-12 hours?  ArmA3 is easily crushing those titles because of re-playability, nearly endless options of customization, building your own szenarios, scripts, addons, islands.   You can even find gametypes and mods, that change the way to play ArmA3. They modify it to be played apart from the original way to play it. (Those mods and missions are Boiling Point, Wasteland, Altis Life RPG)  Some might hit their heads now to a table, as this isnÂ´t the way ArmA is meant to be played. But it shows whats possible with the game and the engine at all =).   This is, what gamers want. A long term motivation (Look at my game hours :D) and a huge sandbox to be entertained for years.  (Sure there are bugs and features, the communitiy is mostly right to complain about) But the steps BIS did to fulfill the wishes of the community, involved changing parts of the team also. Since like 6-7 month the developing and bugfixing gets faster.  ArmA 3 in a nutshell: -A tactic Shooter with simulation elements. -You have to actually think before making a move. -You can have great battles, both coop and team-vs-team. -The Mod support for this game is really great. As above: User created content like islands, content addons, mods, missions, campaigns, replacements. -Even a normal battle between a fireteam gets you harder than it would on every other game here around.   If you search for a game where you are entertained for years, a semi-realistic warfare, combined arms gameplay, an open world sandbox game? Then look no further. Trash the other games and get in soldier!

Arma is a great series of games and the scope of each title is always more impressive than it's predecessor. Yes, like those it follows ARMA 3 has it's bugs, but these are in no way irritating. At most, they are hilarious.... because you become immersed with experience of being a lethal weapon, methodically removing enemy AI from their short lived lives, when all of a sudden the yells and laughs of comrades 'hoovering' in a tank or being insta-killed by randomly exploding vehicles that touched a small pebble, breaks the cycle!   It's a game you have to try out. You can get into the game quite easily and add to your knowledge as you go. But don't be a lone wolf and complain it was boring. Arma is about team work... and not your Call of Duty or Battlefield TDM capture the flag balls...but actual teamwork where communication and learning your place in a squad keeps you all alive! The A.I. on this game is 'effective' - they will suppress, they will surpise and they definetly do more than just flank you from obvious places. It's very dynamic and lonewolfs die quickly... a good squad will have a much higher survival rate!   So get yourself in a game, be a local on the server and join in with 'regulars' to have the best experience.  There is a lot to learn, but ARMA 3's new tutorial system is far superior to older versions of the game and many of the players online are very helpful.   Heaps of content & the workshop has lots more additions. Goto Armaholic for the best and widest range of addons. My only gripe is that they can still be somewhat difficult to install. So it maybe best to use a loader.   I'm a big fan of the Arma series and this one has raised the bar again!  Get your â¥â¥â¥â¥'s off COD & BF and play a real game!!!   11/10

I really hate to say this, but you should wait to get this game until BIS gets it finished, assuming that happens. The reader should realize that I have almost 2000hrs in ArmA2. The 600 or so listed on my profile here is just since it got added to Steam and doesn't count the time pre-Steam.  So, as someone who plays exclusively with friends on listen servers, not on big public servers. As someone who plays mostly CTI maps (remember those BIS?), and as someone who spent most of those almost 2000hrs flying CAS in a jet (remember those BIS?), .......I can honestly say that I'm rather let down by ArmA 3 and it makes me very sad.  The interface has always been clunky from way back in OFP and before. The new backpack system seems to me to just be a reskin of the same thing. It does indeed make it a bit easier to use being able to drag and drop stuff (novel!!), and while I appreciate the work here.....I'd rather have seen the time spent on other things.  To be fair, two of the devs DID spend time locked up in Greece for a stupid reason. I think it was 11 months? This is something that is strictly forbidden to speak of on their forums for some odd reason. But, I understand this had a huuuuuuge impact on their development cycle as it was their two LEAD devs as I understand it. I get the feeling that they got back, and shoved development through in order to compete with the (then) new BF and CoD releases. I personally feel this was a huge, quivering pile of mistake. Because......they aren't really in competition with those games!!! It'd be like saying that chess competes with checkers and monopoly. All board games sure but vastly different. Same here! ArmA II was all about trying to make the game more of a military simulator. Though I think they had to admit some limitations here and there with the tech of the day without making the engine only playable on super computers. ArmA III seems to go away from this and I think it's trying to compete even more now with those other games in some ways.....maybe I'm wrong? It just doesn't feel like the team is as worried about realisim any longer.  For me, the fact that it's set in 2035 is a HHHHUUUUUUUGE turn-off and almost a game breaker right there. That, and there's ONE jet in the game thus far.....one AND it's some old trainer POS to boot.....nice.....well guess this confirms my hunch I've had for a while now. BIS seems to hate fixed wing like Blizzard hates melee! It's all about rotary wing! Which is fine and dandy unless you need an A10 or a Spooky. By 2035 we assume naturally that these have been phased out, so where are their replacements? Hell, at this point I'd be happy with an F15 that I can just fly and do stand-off attacks with from miles away.....oh right that's what the choppers are for!  Am I ranting a bit there? Um, yes sorry, but I was just looking SO foward to this game!!! Heck I even did the pre-order on the delux version!! NOW? Ya I'm kinda not happy about that.  I fire the game up now and then after I see an update downloading. Just to mess around with the undrivable pickups and do target practice with the assault rifles that have recoil like a .45-110 every shot......it's like going to the playboy mansion only nobody's there.  So, I'd say to wait on this game. I'm still playing ArmAII where I can fly fixed wings even in the base game. Oh yes I know...mods mods mods....ya *hangs head*

Bugs, Hackers, glitches, Unfinnished patches, Unreleased vehicles, Just right there would be enough to steer away anyone from purchasing this game. However, even with all that I still will play Arma III. The online multiplayer experiences are pheonominal, and definetly unique. If you've ever played massive online sandbox fps, for example, Planetside 2, you will know the kind of online experiences to expect, however unlike other sandbox MMOs, the experiences you get with Arma, are changing. Its not a repetitive, boring, same old grind. Depending on what server you want to play on, you can find yourself, playing with other players against AIs, using modern military tatics and utilizing resources to save a down player pilot, or you can find yourself running drugs in the cover of night trying to evade player police. As long as I have played Arma III, I cannot say that it has been boring for me. However this game is not for everyone, so if your not into the sandbox effect, i would continue on with your day, but if you enjoy unique experiences, and a endless interaction, then I highly recommend Arma III.

SERVE on lettuce leaves, garnished with reserved egg slices.  Easy 12-Minute Method for Hard-Boiled Eggs: Place eggs in a saucepan large enough to hold them in a single layer. Add cold water to cover the eggs by 1 inch. Heat over high heat just to boiling. Remove from the burner. Cover pan. Let eggs stand in hot water for about 12 minutes for large eggs (9 minutes for medium eggs; 15 minutes for extra large eggs). Drain. Shock the eggs in a bowl of ice water to cool them immediately. Hard-boiled eggs are easiest to peel right after cooling.    Tips   This creamy egg salad can be layered with crunchy lettuce on whole wheat toast for a simple sandwich, or stuffed into cherry tomatoes for an impressive appetizer.  Very fresh eggs can be difficult to peel. To ensure easily peeled eggs, buy and refrigerate them a week to 10 days in advance of cooking. This brief âbreatherâ allows the eggs time to take in air, which helps separate the membranes from the shell.  Hard-boiled eggs are easiest to peel right after cooling. Cooling causes the egg to contract slightly in the shell.  To peel a hard-boiled egg: Gently tap egg on countertop until shell is finely crackled all over. Roll egg between hands to loosen shell. Starting peeling at large end, holding egg under cold running water to help ease the shell off.  Hard-boiled egg storage time: In the shell, hard-boiled eggs can be refrigerated safely up to one week. Refrigerate in their original carton to prevent odor absorption. Once peeled, eggs should be eaten that day.  ENJOY!

With my computer I can only run arma at minimal settings, I cant play multiplayer and I can only play on one of the 3 maps. My machine is 9 years old. Worse still, I can only play for an hour before my game crashes due to the memory leak. Yetâ¦ I have over 320 hours playedâ¦ That is how much this game has to offer. Id say I only experience about 5% of what arma has to offer and just look at my time played. That is how many hours you can put into this game and still be entertained.  Repetition. Compared to Arma 2? This game is horrible. Now don't get me wrong, I love the hell out of Arma 2, a game which I've put more than 460 hours into. I've played everything from Wasteland, Takistan Life, Domination to DayZ. But this game...   Cons:  - The bugs. The desyncs. The clunky gameplay. One would think we'd have a smooth game after all these years, but no. It's the same clunky mechanics and awful netcode (expect those close combat 'But I just put an ENTIRE clip into that guy and he still killed me before I killed him!')  - The recoil mechanics aren't 'realistic', they are so bad that with many guns you simply empty entire magazines regardless of shot number (single or burts) and you will still miss. Where in Arma 2 at least the first shot will generally hit, the guns here are inaccurate as all hell which kills a large portion of the game for me,  - The stamina system is even worse, it runs out extremely fast and there's barely any indicator besides a faint darkening vignette around the edges of the screen to tell you that you're essentially â¥â¥â¥â¥ed if you meet any adversaries. In Arma 2, you can hear your guy gasp for breath and your crosshairs fly all over the screen if you've tried to pull an Usain Bolt.   - Where in Arma 2 a single bullet can take you out, they seem to have appealed to the more mainstream gaming community and implemented some form of 'Oh look, Bob, I'm a bullet sponge.'    Pros:  - The graphics are amazing. Don't expect a well-oiled game experience to match.  - The intro story is good.   I will still not recommend this game. I've tried to play it and enjoy it, but it's a waste of money. But what am I saying? Go listen to those 'crashed car into pole 10/10 would do again' children.

Easily my favourite game right now. While there is less content than ARMA 2 right now, BIS is continually adding more. This game is definitely not for your typical CoD kiddy as it takes patience and strategy which all adds into the experience.   The biggest thing for me is that this is a community game. BIS has simply provided a platform where the community makes limitless mods and missions for the user to enjoy. Speaking of mods, THEY ARE AWESOME! Anything from radio mods, to sound mods, to vehicle and weapon additions, and even entire new maps and game mods (there's even a mech warrior mod).  The immersion in this game is great and I would highly reccomend taking the time to join a community. Doing this, you'll gain access to the real ARMA experience and not Atlis Life/Wastelands. Community events are great and there's basically one out there that would suit any player.  Lastly, this game supports multiple control inputs which is a HUGE plus for me. For example I have essentially 5 control inputs: keyboard, mouse, Track IR, joystick/hotas, and steering wheel/pedals. They all work seemlessly together and allow for some really awesome configurations. For example, the pedals are tri-purpose. I use them for the obvious brake and gas while driving but I additionally use them for analogue leaning as infantry and rudder pedals while flying.

This my first ever game review so, I'll try my best. Basically, what you get with ARMA is open-world warfare. The size of the maps and locations in ARMA bring it to life more than a simple Call Of Duty Map. The graphics are beautiful and show off the true extent of PC Gaming, Simple things such as the movement of smoke whilst flying through it with a helicopter or jet pay off big time. There is a huge extent of weapons and vehicles to choose from to explore the vast world. Multiplayer is fantastic with there being many 'Altis-Life' servers out there such as EUGL or Darkside Gaming. These online servers give you the oppurtunity to make it big as a drug smuggler or serve Altis in the Police Forces and work your way to higher positons. My only let downs with the game is the driving/flying/boating physics and controls. It definately isn't the best game when it comes to vehicles with the steering feeling delayed and sloppy and the damage can be sometimes, ridiculous. There was a time where I drove a vehilce into a tree at around 10 km/h and it blew up. Then another where I crashed a heli out of the sky and everything was fine besides the rotors.   So to sum up the game, if you are looking for an open-world warfare with a great multiplayer community you should definately give it a go, Even though I have never played this as a single-player game it still gets an Easy 8/10 from me.\\  -HDWizzard

ArmA 3 is the best war simulation game you can get today. The different multiplayer gamemodes you can play and all the mods thats in this game is insane, especially the RP communities that starting to become a massive thing in the gaming industry.   Even though ArmA 3 is the most realistic and full of gaming potential, it can be quite hard to find a community that you click with, typically you need to find some friends from outside and get them into this too, Then theres the time consume-  which basicly means, if you got a girlfriend that you have to spent time with, you either have to play ArmA 3 together or drop either ArmA or the GF(This is the best choice aha), then theres also the hardware issues. When I started playing ArmA 3 my Geforce Experience program automatically chose Ultra for all the settings, which my PC didn't really enjoy, so I crashed and lagged a lot, so I chose to look into the configs, and saw that it all was on Ultra, so I turned it to medium.(This was with a single GTX-660TI GPU), and now later I have bought 2(SLI) 970. So what have we learned yet?  Bad things 1st. Community play(Singleplayer is boring and etc.) 2nd. Time consuming. 3rd. Hardware issues.  Good things 1st. Awesome experiences with both RP and other kind of gamemodes. 2nd. Meeting people from all over the world, and forming an virtual community. 3rd. A really good solution if you want some competitive realistic war scenarios. 4th. A lot of online users, so you shouldn't worry about not finding a server for your favourite gamemode.  All in all, I find ArmA 3 one of my favourite games, which is why I have chosen to say that I think you should buy this game if you want something realistic and 'fun' but really time consuming.

By far one of my favourite games!  I've been playing Arma since the good ol' OFP series and have truly enjoyed each new addition to the Armaverse. That being said, the game, and series, are not without its faults. Luckily the faults are often overshadowed by the large modding community which, in my opinion, is one of the best communities out there. Kudos to the devs for creating a game that encourages modding. If it's not in the game yet, you can be almost certain, that someone will mod it in.  If you like milsim, or just want to upgrade to something more tactical and realistic than the COD or BF-series, well give Arma a try. Initially the game might seem confusing, but with the introduction of Bootcamp, new players are guided through the basics of the game, and get a chance to test their skills, before taking on the full Arma experience.  A lot of players play the games single player campaign before embarking on what truly makes Arma great, the multiplayer experience. You'll find a large number of Arma groups, all looking for new members, and no matter what you prefer, be it Marines, Special Forces or Insurgents, there's bound to be a group for you too.  Some of the drawbacks about Arma 3 is, that it's set in a not to distant future, and thus the developers have chosen to 'futurefy' the units and vehicles. Some like it, some don't. In previous installations of Arma, the conflict areas somewhat resembled ongoing conflict areas in the real world, whereas in A3 the conflict initially takes place in the Mediterranean, and covers a conflict between CSAT (Iran and others) and NATO. The island of Altis does look great though, and offers plenty of space for combined warfare. If anything it lacks a bit of forest.  One of the higlights of the game, to me, is the editor. Anyone who's played with LEGO as a child will love the editor. It gives you the chance to create your own missions, and the possibilities seem endless, from the easy and short missions, to the vastly complex ones that require a good amount of scripting. Arma has it all! Plus, with Eden coming along, the editor is about to get even more awesome. A full featured 3D editor, so no more guessing if you've placed the units at the correct spot, or if they're facing the right window etc., Eden delivers big time improvements over the 'classic' 2D editor.  Now I could go on for ages with this review, but essentially here are my thoughts on the game, if you're thinking of buying it.  Buy it: - If you like to play in a more tactical manner than COD/BF - If you like being a part of a massive community, where something new is always being modded in - If you can live with some of the small errors and restrictions by the game-engine, and realizing that the game is under constant development - If you like large scale combined warfare - If you have ever played with LEGO and enjoy creating stuff - If you're looking to get into an Arma group and anjoying the MP community - If you want a game that you can play for ages  Don't buy it: - If you think it's anything like COD/BF/CS:GO - If you think you'll learn the game in 30 minutes - If you can't live with AI that sometimes is â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ - If you have a low spec PC (Arma is horrendously optimized, as of yet, and your FPS WILL drop)

Arma 3, where do I start?   This game is the definition of realistic.   This game is the definition of freedom.   And why is it?  As you might've noticed, this is not a linear campaign shooter like Call of Duty, or Battlefield. This is the game, where you have two gigantic maps (soon a third, but as a DLC). In the base game, you ofcourse have your campaigns and all, but when the game really shines, is with its multiplayer and modding community.  In my entirety of my life, have I never seen this many mods and custom campaigns, etc. in a single game, as I have in Arma 3. It's excellent, and gives you a large variety of options on how to play. From procedurally generated open maps with the freedom of choice where to go, to the more linear - yet awesome campaigns. There's new weapons, new vehicles, even entirely new maps for you to download for free, using the Steam Workshop.  Now, about the multiplayer. When you open up your browser, you'll see a lot of the same game modes. It's a shame that there's only a few select game modes, which really made it through with Arma 3, as I remember Arma 2 had some different and awesome game modes which Arma 3 lacks. Now, if you just want to play with your friends, go ahead and create a server. You can even play with mods, and all of that custom content you've downloaded (this includes game modes, maps, etc.) to keep it fresh for you.  Now that I've talked about the good, let's talk about the bad.  The game suffers heavily from bad optimization. Now, I'm not running a monster rig, but with a GTX 770, I'm able to run every game with relative graphics. My graphics settings in Arma 3 actually don't matter that much, as my FPS remains around the same, even if I select everything on the lowest, or on ultra. If you don't have a powerful computer, or just a mid-range like me, you're in for a really bad time, and should upgrade your PC before attempting to play this game.  To be honest, I'd love to see newer vehicles and weapons from Arma 3, as most of them are wayy outdated by now. Ofcourse there's the mods, but there's not mods for every single thing.   All in all, this is a must-have if you're into military shooters (and have a good rig).

What it means is it involves a lot of running, traveling and it may require a lot of patience. It is almost 90 % traveling and what it does is it makes the 10 % worth it because when you have traveled or ran for a long long time then you wont really be prepered for combat too much. Even though its almost just a walking/running sim or just a waiting sim, when something really does happen you wont be prepered too much and that makes it really thrilling. Not only wont you be as prepered as if you had ran for 40 ft and then gotten shot at, killed them, ran another 40 ft and getting shot at. There's even a pretty good single player you can play for hours. The most popular thing i would assume is the multiplayer and that is because a the single player is mostly scripted and you can go through it over and over and know what to expect. While multiplayer is diffrent because you can walk somewhere, get killed one time, walk to the same place, get killed again then walk there again and not get killed. (Its not actually like that sometimes.) It's a game that has a BIG focus on strategy, teamwork and resourses.   Would i recommend this game? Yes. Thats just my formal opinion. This is a game you will most likely either love or hate. Before you decide get more into the game because its not just all of the same. It's one of those unike games you are likely to RARELY see.

I remember seeing screenshots of Arma 1 and thinking 'Wow, this game must keep me entertained for months', but after obtaining it I quickly changed my mind and thought what a buggy piece of crap this is, me being a somewhat casual gamer back then. The game was a total disaster to me and made me think 'How could they even call this a game?' The best part were the voice commands. Move. To. That. Building. At.. SIX O'CLOCK! Not to mention the game ran like crap. (Only arma players know what crap means.) (This was obviously ~6 years ago, so I was a bit younger then aswell)  Well, I had a friend in xFire who I shared a similar fate with, but for some reason we decided to try it out together anyway. What we did was the sample Seize the area -mission that you can automatically create from the editor. Suddenly the game wasn't so bad after all. Everything that it lacked in the usual things you have in FPS games it gained back in gameplay and the complexity of the game. Suddenly the trademark buggyness and clumsyness of the engine (which is still present) was a feature instead of a problem. We played it for about 60 hours straight after that, downloading mods, missions and whatnot.  Then came Arma 2. Being a moneyless kid I was, I couldn't buy it. So we tried different cracks, playing through hamachi LAN with the same CD-Key and whatnot, but got beaten by the anti-crack software it had built in. Now you might think that's cause of our amateurism, but really it was cause nobody played the game back then and nobody could create working cracks. Literally, there was maybe 1000 players around the world who had bought the game. Eventually I managed to buy the game and spent countless hours on it until it was time to put it on the shelf.  And then, maybe two years later, came DayZ and probably a million more players cause of it.  Suddenly there were keygens, cracks.. - whatever you needed to bypass the protection. Also, the mainstream gamer had found out what kind of possibilites the Arma engine can provide (dayz being the example). This was something the game developers deserved for putting so much effort to the series.  And now, cause of this success, Arma 3 is here. It's basically Arma 1 and 2 with a bigger budget. I wouldn't have ever thought during my Arma 1 days that it would ever get this popular.   What Arma 3 features: - Excellent graphics - The most realistic military simulation there is - Huge map - Good modability: This has always been a strong point in the series, just check Armaholic and steam workshop and you'll find all sorts of things for your liking. - Possibility to design scenarios with endless different ways: Want a mission where you have to sneak through enemy lines and assasinate an officer? You got it. - Excellent co-op gameplay. - Trademark clumsyness to a lot of things, which will become a feature once you get used to it.  But.. if you're a codfag; you need to give the game some time. It's not your usual casual FPS where everything is scripted and whatnot. And get someone to play with.

I Have over 1100 hours on record with this game since Early Access.  The game has become much more user friendly since coming out, if you want a casual to all the way hardcore MILSIM experience, look no further.  Pro's: Huge Scale  Gorgeous visuals  Large selection of weapons  Realistic Ballistics, physics, damage implementation for various calibers, realistic Flight model including but not limited too advanced flight model implementation such as stalls, vortex ring state, damaged instrument panels and etc.  Welcoming community  Insane amount of free mods and maps (Including weapons, textures, sounds for weapons such as DragonFyre sound mod and etc..)  Tutorials that actually teach you how to play and how to not only react to contact and ambushes but also teaches you how to team play as part of a larger assault element and also combined arms (Ever wanted to be in the big boy army and participate in a large scale attack? look no further).  Good single Player Campaign.  Con's  Can still have a steep learning curve, mission making takes practice, more advanced missions scripting requires a decent concept of game script writing  Very very un-optimized for current Gen CPU's. Single thread performance only, can be resource intensive, recommend a i7 CPU for decent game play, takes a beast of a rig to run with everything maxed out in multiplayer (FPS in multiplayer is based off server side FPS and NOT client side aka your PC FPS, hence even powerful pc's can get stutter in large scale multiplayer games).  Can get pretty big in size if you subscribe to a large number of mods  Some mods can interfere with others.  TL:DR Since coming out Arma 3 has become much easier to learn and grasp with new and improved tutorials and scenarios, amazing mod support and close knit community help overcome and issues with this game such as optimization issues and map creation tools. If you do get this game, highly recommend finding a MILSIM unit and or group of players to help guide you in starting out in this game.  My Rig Specs for playing this game (At 1920x1080 with 2x FXAA and view distance of 2500 meters)  i7 3770k Over clocked too 4.1 Ghz 16GB DDR3 10600 RAM EvGA GTX 970 Superclocked (OC 100mhz GPU, 500Mhz Memory) Samsung 840 Pro SSD Windows 10 64bit

The main reason why I bought Arma3 was for the Wasteland mod. I played Arma 2 pretty heavily and I can say for sure that Arma3/Wasteland is far superior than DayZ in every respect except for survival/foraging. I played quite a bit of Arma2 Dayz and I feel that the mod is extremely overrated compared to the other MP experiences Arma has to offer.  This review may be more helpful to those who are thinking about the decision to move to Arma3 from Arma2.  Arma 3 improves upon Arma 2 in many ways. First it reduces the amount of clutter on the keyboard. Now there isn't (what feels like) fifty keys dedicated to command/radio and now there is more of a streamlined feel to the game. That being said, it's extremely necessary to play with voice, as calling out targets/orders is something that is required in this game, unless you are a lone wolf or you are in a rather large group where the need for such things is lessened.  Also, a major update in graphics, which I must say are stunning compared to A2. This doesn't make Arma, but it helps you stay immersed. Needless to say, Arma will  always  be unoptimized, so please, learn simple optimization tricks before giving up after seeing you have <30 frames. It's worth it.  The amount of customizations in this game is extremely helpful/useful. Be warned though, it may take some time before you get the hang of it as Arma, being buggy, has a tendency to make things hard. Plus there's the fact that sometimes a player can get their hands on a fantastic sniper rifle, minus the scope (I'm pointing at you wasteland). So be warned of these situations before you find yourself in one that isn't to your liking.  After all of this I would suggest that people with lower end computers don't buy this game or be prepared to run it on low settings. But the low settings are nothing to be mad about, as they are still pretty damn good, and graphics are not something that you come to Arma for in the first place.   Now for those who haven't experienced the Military Sim feels (you know what I'm talking about)... Arma. Delivers. When played right, it delivers a deep comradery that cannot be gotten from most other games on the market. When you achieve something with your friends, who you sometimes have to place 100% trust in, it can be awe inspiring and can lead to many ecstatic shouts over the radio for doing something seemingly insignificant if seen through eyes of a standard FPS player.  Now about gameplay; Arma requires an extreme amount of patience. Normally you have one or two rounds of fire to get things right or you will be sent to the death screen. Bullets hurt. Really bad. Normally getting hit with one is life threatening if it's normal caliber, but any more than that and you could be facing a bit of a journey back. This normally means 10-20 minutes to regroup and find another battle worth fighting. But don't worry, many of my fondest memories of Arma are from moments that are just random and unexpected, and they don't even require the slightest trace of enemy presence. (  http://i.imgur.com/GgapTFX.jpg  ) <- From Arma2   TL;DR Arma 3 is a much improved upon Arma 2, nothing extremely new here but there's still quite a bit more which makes it worth getting if your computer can handle the game and you can handle the buggyness/playstyle of Arma. It is one of my favorite games and is the leader of its genre, and rightfully so.  For those wondering approximately 300 hours of game time logged on Arma2.

I picked this game up when it first came out and have spent tons of time playing it since then. With mods the game gets even better and more playable, and less 'sci-fi' like. Also, I've never played any of the single player stuff that comes with the game, I only do multiplayer with my group and I really enjoy it. Things to watch out for; you need a fast processor for this game - DO NOT buy it if your CPU isn't over 3.5 M. All of the Arma games are CPU intensive and this one is the worst for it. Don't expect it to be easy - this isn't Call of Duty or some other 'fps' that has the AI standing around waiting for you. They'll hide, shoot at distance and even chase you around. Use real-world tactics, if you're with friends, and see how well they work (they do), think 'stay alert' and you'll survive longer. There's loads of stuff I could say about this game, but really I play it for about 20 hours or so a week and really enjoy it.

This is going to be a pretty long review of ArmA 3 so lets get started. ArmA 3 is an open world Military simulator, designed to capture real war. And it does this fairly well. But I cannnot recommend the game for the following reasons.   Firstly we will start with the Pros and then the Cons.      Pros:         ArmA3 is set on either Stratis, Altis or Tanoa depending if you purchased the DLC or not. Stratis is a good small map with good positions for setting up interesting military operations same with Altis. Tanoa is a Fujian like terrain with many trees and bushes allowing for jungle type warfare scenarios which is both interesting and engauging.       The game is highly moddable you can write scripts to add new functionality or create models that create new types of gameplay. Such as new weapons or vehicles. The engine is powerful in terms of versitility but not so great in other aspects.       Vehicle,uniforms and weapon content is quite wide in terms of what you get for the base game but all the other DLCs add a fair bit more than what the base game offers including a new jungle type map.       The game is visually appealling with post processing effects including 16bit HDR and Your basic bloom effects. It also has high resolution textures for all vehicles players and objects.      There exists a pretty wide range of game mode variation from Invade & Annex to KoTH all the way to GTA remake called Altis Life.      The games weather is a real testiment to what TrueSky can do it's beautiful the sky along with the cloud and weather effects. combined withe HDR the game comes quite close to actual real life sky colouring. Coupled with the weather effects sound improvements that game with Tanoa eliminated the tin sounding thunder claps.        Cons:         Game suffers extreme bottlenecks in the rendering loop with super-sampling. A resolution of 200% set in ArmA 3 results in a massive drop in videocard usage. to nearly 28% This is probably due to ArmA 3 not feeding enough work to the videocard as a result the videocard is always waiting for an update.      Game depends on single core clock performance because of how the threading model works. Simply put the game main thread sit on a single core with worker threads sent to other cores, those worker threads report back to the main thread so in the instance that a worker thread is in the geometry rendering or texture rendering the main-loop is in a wait-state for the sub-threads to report back their status as a result CPU and GPU usage drop like a brick.       Artificial Intelligence is definitely not intelligence the AI are smart enough to aimbot you thats about it and you have to use external scripts to fix something that should already be in place. I mean tab into zues and they have a missile reticle on your player behind a build / tree. They drive and are as smart as your little toys you used to have as a kid that would crash into a wall turn randomly in 1 direction then move forward and repeat. Half the time never actually getting around the obstacle      The community is rude and generally arrogant, you ask certain questions and they will attack your coding because you did 1 thing wrong instead of actually pointing out the problem they bash what you did. They are certainly not real programmers in any respect.       The scripting engine is yes versitile and functional but thats about it. Many nuances exist in the scripting engine and documentation for it is dismal and lacking. Edited by the community through much trial and error. And assumed functionality from previous experience. Python or Lua which Lua is more commmonly found in other games as a script API are known to have very good documentation as they are so wide spread SQF on the other hand is a mess a god damn mess.       Networking wise the game doesn't scale beyond 40 - 50 players depending on the server, but in general for example KoTH with all it's server-side mod components and client side it still suffers massive FPS drops when clients get close together ArmA 3 is a military simulator engine is people repeatedly try to treat it like GTA or an MMO type game engine which it is not, and so performance overall suffers considerably when we get > 50 players online.       Mods don't follow a standard of work, as such anyone can publish ArmA 3 mods, even if they may contain catastrophic bugs that lead to memory leakage in the sense of external dlls or scripts.       Scripts also don't follow a standard of work, standardisation is almost non-existent in game and people often slap scripts together and hope for the best. Without considering the consequences of that script.      Code theft and thievery is rampant 1 community develops something the other has to steal it from that community. People also try to threaten about code supposably owned by previous communities which it is only owned by them if money was to change hands and or contracts were signed which if they were not would not matter by default you own the code rights.       Apex DLC is only worth the money if you only care about the map the map is the most interesting part of Tanoa thats about it.       Many missions are highly toxic and encourage disgusting gameplay behaviour and the related. wasteland,Altis Life and KoTH are just mere reincarnations of Grand Theft Auto, Call of Duty and DayZ modification. May as well be.       Gameplay becomes boring an uninteresting after being both drained by the communities and the script engine not cooperating for whatever undocumented stupid reason.       The wiki documentation is a mess a total mess certain pages re-route to completely unrelated pages repeatedly, with a nesting effect there is no class inheritence or order, the wiki is mostly chaotic and messy.       Communiities have a real sense of entitlement just because you wrote it you should share it, this is not the case. With the above stated 'theivery' of code. People feel they deserve it in the community because of knowledge they contributed to the wiki etc. They are entititled to sweet f.a .     Thats just my little breakdown and rant about how bad the game is and it's problems. If bohemia were to fix the framerate problems many people experience from people with I7-6700K at 4.0Ghz to I7-5820K at 3.3 Ghz then I might consider it recommedable, but this game is still suffering framerate problems 2 years since it's release. The community hasn't cleaned up it's act and the game still does poor usage of videocard resources it should be using a lot more. The engine is old and archiac and requires both 64bit addressing in order to help the large maps without having to stream the data by dynamically loading and unloading data on the fly to get around the 32bit memory problem. 64bit memory would also allow more resources to be utilised because more threads often require more RAM. For each of their instances.        This is my first and last Bohemia game I will buy

If you came here because saw some youtube of great playz and got hyped on this game go and watch some longplay footage without editing or watch live-stream. Then you may change your mind. Because regular gameplay is way different from carefully edited best-ofs. This game has these nice moments separated by long periods of struggling with interface and trying not to die from glitches.  Is is not kind of game you can grab on sale and have fun with. You can't start playing this game without having someone to introduce you to it because singleplayer is really limited and multiplayer is quite inaccessible to uninitiated newbie. So if you wonder if you could just take it and play for some hours having fun then forget about it - you wont. And if some of your friends told you to play with them then sure, by all means take it - even fighting with sticks with friends is fun so Arma3 can be too ;).  You can read negative reviews about game optimization. These are reviews from somebody who probably never played actual Arma3 - game runs great, looks great, works smooth with hi-rez and hi-fps. But then who buys Arma to play Arma? Not many. Obviously. People install Arma to play mods. But mods, that are lifeblood of gaming and salvation of the industry [sarcasm!], are usually made by wannabe-pros-script-kids who plant hack over hack in mod in attempt to implement anything. Constant loops designed to eat cpu cycles, photo-quality textures for sexy female models, shiny new guns with more polygons than whole aircraft. Then couple of these are bunched together on one server, with possible conflicts and no concern about limitations of average user's hardware. People cry that their powerful pcs can't handle it but it is terrible quality mods that kill it and slow your game to crawl. Game is optimized but mods are not curated so every piece of random hacks are allowed and people who run mods expect the game engine to somehow detect bad code and optimize it. Want high fps? Dont install poor mods. Refuse to play unoptimized mods and encourage others to stop playing them - maybe this way you will tell mod-devs to start thinking about their work [hint: they will just stop making mods].  The problem is that beside vehicle and bullet mechanics things go wrong in this production. Physics is bad - you will make backflips with your APC or die from touching dynamic object. Infantry controls are terrible - probably infantry unit is not required in simulator for army so what you receive here is human character that is controled like a tank. Nobody cared to plan and hone useful user interface to provide smooth control system for player character. You get avatar to control and whole keyboard of buttons to make him move. You can customize it to your will, you can use all external devices you like - but it is up to you to make it work. And even when you make it work as you want you will still have game with unfinished mechanic for infantry:  - your gear doesn't limit your movement so you can carry kgs of equimpent and you will crawl, crouch and stand up at the same speed.  - you cannot even cancel action - you started doing something you are sitting duck.  - missing animations and movement options you would expect from combat-sim. If you can think about doing something you can't do it. Numerous games accustomed us to make quick combat movements, sliding under/over obstacles, hiding behind cover or jumping over walls, entering through the windows and so on so it is painful to be unable to do it here. You cannot even pull out weapon while walking or switch to binoculars while lying down.  - carrying heavier weapon in your hands feels like holding a handgun - you can run around with it feeling no inertia or being slowed down. Some arcade games feel more realistic than Arma.  Game wasn't built around infantry, it is not FPS by heart, this is vehicular combat sim with driver/pilot and gun operator. Infantry units are implemented as VR training for rookies - learning the bullet behavior for long distance shooting, practicing mildot ranging, operating launchers, working with map and team communication.  You won't have smooth close-mid range combat with guns.  This part of the engine was hacked into the existing system and barely works.  Unfortunately.

So the campaign is complete. A lot of folks are still having the BF4 or A3 discussion (argument). Here's what I found. A3 is not without its faults. One of the biggest apects of the game is that it's aimed at the 'thinker'. What I mean by that is that you have endless ways to achieve your goals, but yes in being a milsim you can be taken out by a lucky shot from a guy you never saw (with pinpoint AI targeting) from 500yrds away.   For some folks that's the heart of endless frustration and this is not the game for you. BF4 shouldn't be bashed either, it's simply for a group of folks that want action and eye candy - and it delivers on both of those in spades. A3 has amazing visuals in my opinion, yet they are harder to appreciate because so much tweaking is required to get decent FPS while keeping some of the visual goodies.   It's the fact that A3 is ridiculously hard sometimes, and requires a huge time investment compared to most games, that make it so satisfying when everything finally goes right. A3 gives you a sense of accomplishment like no other when everything hits the fan and you (or your teammates) quick thinking pays off for a win. Being able to jump into almost any vehicle or aircraft leave you feeling that you can be the ultimate ____________ (tank driver, helo pilot, fixed wing ace etc...).   Yes BF4 has some of these components, but delivered in a completely different way. Run, gun, get shot a bunch of times, hide, heal, and do it over again. And that's completely ok if that's you're style of gameplay and what you enjoy. A3 plan, plan, plan some more, cross a huge amount of terrain that can literally take hours on foot, and get shot by a dude you never saw, or...) make the hard win. You will dump huge amounts of time into A3 to be decent at it (plenty of folks don't have that kind of time to commit). BF4 get on..play for a match or two and leave if you want.   BF4 has some great DLC's the latest carrier edition looks awesome. A3 has mod...after mod...after mod. With a workshop full of missions (horrible to great), plus a community that's pretty engaging and helpful.   For me it's A3 all the way!

This game is hands down the best shooter ever made. It is a very immersive game that has features that make it feel like real life. You get injured and if you heal you will walk slower, carry too much and you won't be able to move, realistic stamina, etc. The amount of weapons and vehicles is nice but nowhere near the competitors. Yet those few weapons have the most realistic damage and ballistics of any game I've played.  Now after seeing that you are probably asking why I didn't suggest this game to others. Well the game has a lot of cool features and is very promising in all the different ways you can play. But the game is unplayable at times and is very unreliable. In single player a $2000 dollar computer will run at 40-50 fps on all maxed out video settings. (That being one of the major faults of the game itself; a game shouldn't require two to three thousand dollars for a computer to run single player at subpar frame rates.) That same single player also has one of the worst AI systems in a game. If you're in the line of fire prone with your group of guys they will shoot you to get to the enemy. This happens more often than you would think, and itâs such a problem your squad mates will often kill each other. The enemy AI is far superior in combat and you will find yourself leaving your AI squad behind so you can actually accomplish missions because they tend to get the attention of the enemy AI which seems to target you first no matter what. The enemy AI can see you through bushes 800m away crawling through the 3ft tall grass. So if you want a stealth shooter go somewhere else. In fact if you want a better AI and squad experience go buy the original Ghost Recon because it had a better AI and squad system than this game.   WHO CARES ABOUT SINGLE PLAYER JOHN!   Ok then, so you give up on the single player and you go to multiplayer expecting a similar experience without having to worry about the AI. You'll start up a moderate sized 40 man server that has a ping of 30 when you join that is about full and your system will bog down to 10-15 fps. You go around a corner checking for enemies in a town and you won't be able to move your gun fast enough and you'll get owned over and over. If you try to be in a vehicle with a person who has a junk computer, good luck seeing anything.  All in all, great features on a horrible performance platform, and to make up for it you need a server for a computer.

ArmA III is quite different from most other first person shooters. As to be expected since it is a military simulator. With it's clunky UI, desync problems, unexplained gameplay, complicated controls, and many other bugs, it is clearly not perfect. However, when you get past the UI, and have played the game long enough to understand how it works, ArmA III offers some of the best experiences in video gaming. There's nothing quite like a 100 vs 100 match that turns the colossal Altis map or the still giant Stratis map into a war torn battlefield. The true heart to this game is the mods, and boy are there a lot of them! To start, I would suggest checking out Altis Life, Battle Royale, and Wasteland. These mods add so much life to the game. Many of these mods feel like complete individual games themselves.  In short, though there may be some bugs and a steep learning curve, there is no doubt that ArmA III offers arguably the best multiplayer experience in video gaming.  - 9/10 would glitch again

I really want to love Arma, but I just cant bring myself to. It's the most realistic game ever, and it has probably a lifetimes worth of content. Beautiful graphics and the complexity of the gameplay isn't actually all that daunting once you get used to it. But thats not the problem. The problem is the dog-dirt AI. Its seriously the worst AI I have ever seen in a video game, EVER. I actually cannot describe how awful it is.   Should you attempt to use AI to help you drive a vehicle, God have mercy on your soul. Try and be the gunner? The driver is going to do his best to run into walls and flip the tank in a ditch. See an enemy? Well then he is going to turn the tank around, expose the weak rear armor, and stop in an open field. Tell him to move? Nope, suddenly they forgot how to obey commands and do a weird back and forth jerking roll thing. Try and be the driver? The gunner in a tank with thermal optics will somehow miss a tank sitting 3 feet in front of him. Your infantry teammates will engage the enemy by breaking cover, running into the middle of the street, and spraying on full auto. Vehicles constantly get stuck on rocks, lampposts, trees, ditches, ect. Sometimes they won't spot an enemy in the open while they are being used as target practice, and other times they pull of aimbot level first-shot headshots from 500m while standing upright. Helicopters and planes are more effective as kamikaze weapons, and single enemies with rifles can easily take out a wing of attack helos.   I really really want to love this game, but its virtually impossible to enjoy with AI teammates. I have every AI enhancement mod I can find, nothing helps. Every time I come back to it I get so mad. Whether its my M1 driver stopping in an open field and then un-learning how to drive so we can be RPG fodder or my gunner in an apache refusing to engage enemy infantry in the open leading to an early demise, the AI in this game is insanely poor. It makes the AI out of battlefield 2 look like rocket science. AI able to take the initiative and get in a technicals .50 without being specifically ordered to approach the vehicle, and then you having to get in and switch spots for 10 minutes to finagle them out of a passenger seat into the obviously useful position is a pipe dream in this game. Its super enjoyable to walk around and play in Zeus mode, but unless you have great internet you are going to get very, very, very upset.
